A new type of siren has been ordered for installation on the United States liners Manhattan and Washington, supplementing the foghorns which are now in use, it was announced yesterday. The new horns, known as Jessen "howlers," are designed to cast their warning sounds to great distances, although they will not be heard by passengers on the ships on which they are carried.

Above the gleeful squeals of young New York, attending the first matinee of the circus yesterday, arose the first rumblings of discontent among the ranks of the performers in the Greatest Show on Earth. (The capital letters were supplied by Dexter Fellows.)

Pasquale Rubino's opera "The Tread of Ariadne" is scheduled for its first performance at an "opera concert" in Town Hall on May 6. Or so the announcement read. It sounded a little curious. Reading further, one discovered a synopsis dealing with Theseus, the Minotaur and Crete.

THE author of this book speaks with knowledge and authority, for he is director of the Bureau of Health and Public Instruction of the American Medical Association and he has been Commissioner of Health of Racine, Wis., and has held various other important posts in the safeguarding of the public health.

KATONAH, N.Y., March 31. -- The Brookwood Labor College, at which workers from all parts of the United States and many foreign countries are schooled in the theories of labor and educated for labor leadership, today held its Twelfth Commencement, graduating twenty-nine students.

BOSTON, March 29. -- Clarence De Mar is getting ready for the next Boston marathon by hitch-hiking over a little interval of 100 miles between his home in Keene, N.H., where he teaches in the normal school, and Boston University, where he is taking a course of evening lectures.

The monkey house is always the most popular spot in any zoo. Just so, any character in fiction who has a way with apes or monkeys or chimpanzees -- from Mowgli to Tarzan -- always finds a fascinated following of readers. In "The Monkey God" Gerald Porter accidentally strikes up a great friendship with the langurs of Central India. They are gray apes with black faces and little black hands like a pickaninny's.

France was struck later than many other countries by the depression, and it may be that she will be feeling it most when they begin to emerge from it. However, it is hard to prophesy as so much depends upon what the present Cabinet is able to do with the Chamber of Deputies, which for some time past has been gradually encroaching upon the powers of the Executive in matters of budget and appropriations.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP). -- The temporary air mail set-up was defended today by the Second Assistant Postmaster Genera], Harllee Branch, who described allegations of favoritism as "ridiculous on their face" and "made for political purposes."

Professor Herman Feldman of Dartmouth College has been adjudged the winner in an essay competition held by The Town Crier magazine of the League for Political Education, it was announced yesterday by George V. Denny Jr., editor of the magazine and associate director of the league.

From the moment President ROOSEVELT was able to announce that a strike had been averted in the automobile industry many eyes were fixed on the board created to carry out the terms of the White House agreement. It was widely felt that the three men to be named to that board, one by industry, one by labor and one by the Government, would largely hold in their hands the ultimate fate of the President's efforts.

WARRENTON, Va., March 31. -- In spite of disagreeable weather and ground soft from heavy rain, the point-to-point races held this morning proved very successful. There was a good entry list and no accidents. Great enthusiasm was expressed by the sportsmen present, for this type of racing is new to this section.

THE first anniversary of the loss of the airship Akron, aviation's most costly tragedy in terms of human life, draws near. About a week after that anniversary, on April 9, the Akron's sister ship, the proud Macon, largest, swiftest, most efficient airship ever launched, will start out with the fleet in Pacific waters for extensive war game practice.

Delegates from nearly forty colleges in the Middle Atlantic States will attend a regional conference of the National Student Federation of America at Barnard College and Washington Square College of New York University tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- Liquidation of May corn and oats developed early today on the Board of Trade, causing a decline of about a cent a bushel from Thursday's finish to new levels on the current downturn, but all grains rallied sharply and the finish was at about the top.

One hundred and eighty-eight students have been named on the honor roll for the first semester of the current academic year in the evening division of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, Dean John T. Madden announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Secretary Perkins and Harry L. Hopkins, Federal emergency relief administrator, will be among the speakers at the American Red Cross convention meeting here April 9 to 12.

THIS is one of the finest books on America's pioneer days that we have had. Davy Crockett has thus far fared less well in biographies for younger readers than has Daniel Boone. yet he is as appealing and as picturesque a figure, and one ready made for the story teller.

WESTPORT, Conn., March 31. -- The will of Mrs. Mary A. Bedford, widow of Edward T Bedford, leaves the bulk of an estate valued at $500,000 to her children, Charles E. Bedford of Greenwich, Frederick T. Bedford of Greens Farms, Mrs. Emily Sard of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Mrs. Grace Lloyd of Greenwich. Their share will be about $440,000.

Dividends declared in March were larger than in the corresponding month of 1933, making the second month this year to show a gain over last year. Payments ordered by 1,029 corporations totaled $216,827,492, against $197,702,862 for 1,002 companies in March, 1933.

BERLIN, March 24. -- A new word monster dominates Germany's foreign and economic policy. It is "Grossraumwirtschaft." Literally translated, it means "large space economy." In practice it signifies adjustment of national economy to the economy of a larger region through regional agreements among neighboring or related States able to supplement one another and to supply one another's wants.

NEWARK, N.J., March 31. -- The New Jersey State Emergency Relief Administration, which served as the Civil Works Administration in this State, started today replacing the CWA set-up by the new Works Department of the State ERA.

BERLIN. IT was almost inevitable that Oswald Spengler's new book, "The Hour of Decision," which drew such wide notice, should quickly be answered by a publication inspired by the new German Government. The Spengler book and its English edition were discussed in THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review on Sunday, Feb. 11.

IN all his work -- novelettes, short stories, biographies, critical studies -- Stefan Zweig reveals one gift which stands out predominantly -- the gift of story-telling. He was born to tell stories, and even when he is not writing fiction he handles his work as a master of narrative.

The possession of a load of money made Elodie Charlton feel there was nothing on earth she couldn't have. She was young, golden-haired and beautiful, and most people were delighted to agree with her, though her aunt warned her that she was unbearably headstrong.

MEMORIAL exhibitions need not of necessity be large and exhaustive in order to communicate an artist's significant contribution. This is proved by the show that opened on Tuesday at the Macbeth Galleries, in which we find securely drawn to synthesis the beautiful landscape art of Charles H. Davis, who died last August.

Expenditures made by the Class 1 railroads in 1933 for new equipment and additions and betterments to property used in transportation were smaller than in any other year since 1923, according to the Bureau of Railway Economics. In the decade from 1923 to 1933, capital expenditures were about $7,500,000,000, or an average of more than $670,000,000 a year, compared with $103,947,000 in 1933.

NO one interested in the political ferment which is post-war Germany, or in the spirit of bitter disillusionment underlying that ferment, can afford to miss this striking autobiography by Ernst Toller. Equally, no one interested in sheer adventure will be able to resist this vivid document describing the author's participation in one of the grimmest and most important adventures of our time.

AFTER two years in Lower California, where he had leased a ranch and tried to build up a cattle business, Tom Cloud found himself still beset by the same elusive malignance that had been draining his herds almost from the day he came. against which he had tried every defense in vain.

A HATCHET, a pruning knife, two bundles of twigs representing faggots, six horseshoes and sixty-one nails for them were recently paid to King George, through his Remembrancer, by the Corporation of the City of London and the Sheriffs of the County of Middlesex at the Law Courts in London.

PALO ALTO, Calif., March 31 (AP). -- Jimmy LuValle, University of California at Los Angeles, quarter miler, failed today in his attempt to better Ben Eastman's 440-yard mark and Bill Cart's 400-meter record, running the lap in 47.4 seconds in the Stanford-U.C.L.A. meet.

A YEAR ago we gave some space to certain investigations which had been conducted by Dr. Charles B. Lipman of the University of California and which indicated that he had found living bacteria within meteorites that had come from outer space.

What started out to be a dull holiday market gradually developed yesterday into one of the strongest and most active short sessions in the last two months. With a large part of the financial community absent. owing to the Good Friday holiday that had been observed by all the Exchanges, it was expected that stocks would drift through a desultory two-hour trading period.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has accepted the invitation of the committee for the Rainbow Ball to serve as honorary chairman of that event, which is taking place Friday night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton.

IT is an exceedingly far cry from the Starrett High School of today, located at the corner of Forty-seventh Street and Eleventh Avenue, surrounding with its dingy walls an entire city block, housing during school hours nearly three thousand boys and more than a hundred teachers, to those ancient groves of the days when Greece was young.

ONCE more Spring is in the air. Once more the northward winging robins sing. Once more there is an orderly hum around dozens of widely scattered Winter quarters, for the annual circus season is opening.

MR. MOONEY'S book effectively develops one particular side of an argument, in which every one interested in the political and economic life of this country must join. The author wishes to prove that a ready and objective understanding of the fundamentals of economics, which he insists are simple and self-evident if properly studied, would contribute much toward the establishment of what he calls a "healthier equilibrium" in our national economy.

PARIS, March 31 (AP). -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gordon Switz, young Americans, were represented by the investigating magistrate, Andre Benon, tonight as being "genuinely sorry" for the part the police said they had confessed to having played in an international spy ring.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 31. -- The University of Michigan team tonight captured the National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championship for the fifth time in the last eight years.

LOS ANGELES, March 31. -- Militant communistic activity in the United States at this time is centred in the Imperial Valley of Southern California, ranchers of the Imperial Valley assert, and they expect the "grand blow-up" to occur next week, when the cantaloupe picking season is on.

BELGRADE, March 31. -- Captain Ernst Roehm, chief-of-staff of the Nazi Storm Troops, has announced he will arrive at Dubrovnik in Dal matia next Thursday by air from Berlin. The German envoy in Belgrade, Minister von Heeren, and members of the German and Yugoslav trade delegations, who are negotiating a new commercial treaty, arrived at Dubrovnik today.

A REFRESHING rebel roams the pages of David Garth's first novel. We meet Reed Haldane as he steps from a secure and lucrative position to shake off the Bonds of Babbitt and finds something he likes to do. Like other young men whose wealth has been earned by a preceding generation, he found Yale a place for football, hockey, carousal, costly scrapes.

THE presence of "New Faces" on Broadway is proof of any number of things -- but especially of the fact that there is still persistence in the world. Other revues may be produced with money; "New Faces" was produced with persistence.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The special Senate committee investigating bankruptcies and receiverships indicated today that it had no authority to investigate charges that the Interborough Rapid Transit Company of New York City had gone into a receivership mainly to get rid of leases on lines of the Manhattan Railway Company so it could avoid payment of dividends on Manhattan stock.
Charles M. Schwab sailed yesterday on the Italian liner Rex for a month's trip abroad, He was as optimistic as ever and reaffirmed his belief in the fundamental soundness of American business.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had received notices of the granting of options on stock to officers or employes of three companies. Its announcement read:

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Social interest in -Asheville centres around the approaching annual Asheville Kennel Club show that will be held here April 10 and 11. More than 400 entries are expected in this event, which is sanctioned by the American Kennel Club.

BOSTON, March 29. -- The most surprising incident to date in the present session of the General Court is the 7-to-4 report of the House Committee on Ways and Means in favor of the establishment of a lottery system to be operated by the State with drawings permissible as often as once a month.

WILDWOOD, N.J., March 31. -- James R. (Sonny) Fraser, Seaview's 17-year-old star, starting to defend his Eastern States Easter golf laurels, stayed close to par today in playing two match-rounds in a cold rain over the Wildwood Golf Club's course.

The old guard of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association parried the bold thrusts of the newcomers for individual laurels last night as the forty-first annual championships came to a close at the Hotel Commodore.

RECENTLY Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, head of the Reichsbank, expressed to me the opinion that the economics of National Socialism were of secondary importance as compared with the political, cultural and social aspects. In contrast to Marxian Socialism, National Socialism was not essentially an economic movement.

ROMANCES of the skyscraper are usually trite, mediocre tales in which the superficially entangled lives of feminine office workers and their bosses occupy the centre of the stage. But here that species of novel is conceived and told from an entirely new and impressive angle -- for the skyscraper itself is the dominating force of the whole story in the course of construction and in completion the colossus which rules the characters and their destinies.

ALBANY, March 31. -- Governor Lehman declared in a statement this evening that it was "the plain, inescapable duty" of the Legislature to launch without delay a sweeping investigation of the "relations, past and present, between public utilities and any one in the service of the State Government."

THE NEW DEALERS" shows no lively traces of a new deal in the Washington snoop-and-snipe school of literature. It hobbies along in the trail worn by people who used to do trick titles with "Mirrors" in them, or run "Merry-Go-Rounds," and it shows a dismal lack of imaginativeness.

Miss Nan C. Lawler, former property clerk in the City Home on Welfare Island, failed to appear at the District Attorney's office yesterday morning to surrender, under indictments charging forgery and destruction of public records, and her arrest was ordered by Assistant District Attorney Harold W. Hastings.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Increasing agitation for the remonetization of silver and restoration of enforcement of the anti-trust laws, suspended by the NRA, are problems giving concern to the Democratic leaders in the Senate, who view the movements as possible issues in the November elections.

THE spies Mrs. McKenna knew were very different from those whose mephitic tales writhe through the pages of most books that pretend to open the doors upon spydom, especially international spydom. For one thing, they seem to have been more efficient than the professional espionage agents who work on salaries and think nothing of selling out to the enemy and then double-crossing both new and old employers.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, March 31 (AP). -- Blazing a new golf trail, Gene Sarazen, former American and British open champion, and Joe Kirkwood, the Australian trick-shot star, arrived here today after an 850-mile airplane hop from San Juan, Puerto Rico.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Eighteen cedar trees from the Mountains of Lebanon, symbolizing the "enduring friendship" of the people of the Near East for the people of America, were accepted on behalf of the latter today by Mrs. Roosevelt, acting for the President at a ceremony at Arlington Cemetery.

WHOLLY unexpected was the Whitney Museum's decision prematurely to close for the season. This served to cancel the exhibition of work by Philadelphia artists, scheduled to open to the public last Wednesday. The development, it was announced, grew directly out of "much criticism leveled against the PWAP" and "deflected toward the Whitney Museum," of which Juliana Force, chairman of the PWAP New York regional committee, is the director.

FRANK BUCK snorted and chuckled as he sat back in a swivel chair with his feet on the desk and his hat on his head, all in a little cubicle high above the skyline in Rockefeller Center. He had been asked an indiscreet question, which was:

The "law's delay" and other diseases of our legal process have been sufficiently diagnosed. What we need now are practical prescriptions of remedial methods. One comforting thing is that the best of our judges not only recognize the pathological conditions but are wisely insistent upon early reforms.

THERE are authors who can make interesting even the most uninspiring subject; but there also are subjects which remain enthralling even in the telling of a not particularly brilliant author. It is in this second category that the subject of the present book belongs.

MOSCOW, March 31. -- F.A. Levanovsky, one of the best-known Soviet aviators, who rescued James J. Mattern in Siberia last year, was painfully injured today in the crash of his plane at Kaluchin Bay, while flying to the aid of eighty-nine members of the Chelyuskin expedition, stranded on ice floes north of the eastermost tip of Siberia.

Two men who described themselves as Edgewood Silverman, 32 years old, of 310 West Fory-ninth Street, and Fred Massey, 24, of 606 Eighth Avenue, were arrested yesterday and charged with grand larceny in connection with the loss of $8,000 worth of rare stamps by Kossoff Meghrig, a philatelist, of 87 Nassau Street.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga. -- With the end of the Lenten season social and sport events will be numerous at this resort from now on. College and boarding school students, prolonging their vacations in the South, will be active on the social calendar with dinner dances, dinner parties, private teas, tennis tournaments, cruises and horseback rides.

RECENT seasons have given us so many fairly good novels of the Southern mountains that "Our Bed Is Green" will be in grave danger of being lost and indistinguishable among its numerous predecessors. This is a fate it does not altogether deserve.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in March was the slowest of any full month since February, 1933. Sales in March, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 29,913,969 shares. This compares with 56,834,010 shares in February, and 20,088,664 in March a year ago.

WITH numerous stretches of road in New York and other States suffering from "one of the worst Spring break-ups experienced in automobile history," there is need for increasing the funds for highway maintenance, instead of diverting motor tax receipts to other purposes, in the opinion of J.R. Crossley, chairman of the New York State Highway Users Conference and vice president of the Automobile Club of New York.

Price-fixing under an NRA code was upheld yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox in a decision against the Spotless Dollar Cleaners, Inc., which had been awaited by Recovery Administration officials whose legal staffs are busy preparing other code-enforcement cases.

SEVILLE, March 31. -- The revival of Seville's world-famous Holy Week festival this year appears to have brought with it the wave of reaction feared so much by the Spanish Marxists, who regard religions as the "opium of the masses."

EIGHTEEN cedars of Lebanon have been sent by the people of the Near East as a gift to this nation. A message which accompanied the announcement of the unique contribution stated that the trees were dispatched in appreciation of aid extended by the United States through the Near East Relief, "whose memorable work during and after the World War saved the lives of hundreds of thousands of orphans and helpless refugees."

During the last decade many of the States have turned to the sales tax for revenue. It is reported that twenty-six States have already enacted some form of sales taxation. These are variously known, according to the basis of assessment, as taxes on gross receipts, gross sales, local turnover, retail sales,

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The New York Central Railroad today asked approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission to borrow $2,500,000 from the Public Works Administration to buy 37,000 tons of rails and necessary track materials.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Administration of the Immigration Service on Ellis Island is approved and amplification of its present powers, facilities and equipment is recommended in a special committee report made public today at the Department of Labor.

Professor John Shapley, head of the fine arts department of the University of Chicago, and other officers of the College Art Association were re-elected yesterday at the closing session of its annual meeting at the headquarters, 137 East Fifty-seventh Street.

THE charges made by Dr. William A. Wirt have focused attention once more on the so-called brain trust, and, in the halls of Congress as well as in other debating points of the nation, questions such as these are being asked: What is the brain trust?

Interest in Rugby, which has been gradually increasing since its revival in the East in 1928, is expected to reach its greatest height with the invasion of the Cambridge University team this week. An elaborate program has been arranged for the visitors, who are scheduled to arrive on the Cunarder Berengaria on Wednesday.

THIS Plutarch quotation leads one to look for depressing realism. But "Frogs Die in Earnest" is for the most part a good adventure story -- straight narrative, full of action, quite a bit of humor, with a love story running through it. The hero is Rat-Lieutenant Frederick Francis Tyax of the British Navy.

ALBANY, March 31. -- Declaring their provisions too sweeping, Governor Lehman today vetoed two bills which would have permitted local authorities to assess State land, exclusive of improvements, for school and highway purposes. The measures were sponsored by Assemblyman Howard N. Allen, Republican of Dutchess.

PROFESSOR ALBERT EINSTEIN has become a citizen of the world. An exile from Germany, the great physicist now follows the practice of teaching part of the year at Princeton and the remainder in Paris. Wherever he goes he takes his violin.
IT is only recently that gardeners have rediscovered their noses -- and in consequence a "bloodless revolution" is taking place. With gardens of old, fragrance was always closely associated.

LONDON, March 22. -- Part of the land adjoining Stoke Poses Churchyard, known throughout the world for its association with Gray's "Elegy," has been acquired by the Penn-Gray Society. It is to be converted into an Elegy Memorial Garden, thus preserving for all time the lovely landscape immortalized by the poet.

A fair sign that the depression has actually turned the fatal corner is that it has become a tremendously popular subject for light fiction. Kathleen Norris uses it for the background of her light-hearted, breezy "Manhattan Love Song." Two boys and two girls, fresh from Stanford University, descend upon New York with their eyes open, prepared to buck the depression.

Brightly inconsequential conversation in the English manner makes this farcical tidbit entertaining reading. There is so much comfortable drinking of side-cars gin and tonic, whisky and soda, that it is a thirst-making book. The drinking is all very merry, and the resulting bad heads are ridiculous rather than painful.

The biological researches now being conducted in this country are so numerous and so detailed that "taken all together they are too much for one individual to follow successfully," according to Dr. William H. Howell, Professor Emeritus of Physiology at Johns Hopkins University.
BERLIN, March 31. -- Attempts to revive the anti-Jewish boycott of a year ago were reported today from Nuremberg and other places in Franconia but the movement has not reached serious proportions.

PROFESSOR COLE'S book will have special interest for readers who have been accustomed to think of the period from 1850 to 1865 mainly in terms of politics, constitutional disputation and the military and naval operations of civil war.

The story opens in a court room where Nicholas Trench, a rising young sculptor, is being tried on the charge of having murdered a man named Osborne. Trench is acquitted, but he soon learns that there are many persons, including some that he had supposed to be his friends, who still believe him to be guilty.
The State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board granted yesterday an extension of two weeks to holders of liquor licenses in which to apply for renewals.

OF course Sir Frederick and I on our first Spring trip to The States came prepared for many surprises in the way of gardens and in gardening ways. As is perhaps not unusual in such cases, these surprises lay largely where we least expected to find them.

C.J. Winninger was the high-over-all gunner at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He took the trophy by breaking 91 out of 100 targets. N.E. Sprague, who had a card of 79, 10-89, won the high handicap cup. B.M. Higginson, 83, scored in Class A; R.W. Bates, 81, 4 -- 85, in Class B, and O. Agathon, 67, 21 -- 88, in Class C.
WEST POINT, N.Y., March 31. -- Army crushed C.C.N.Y. in the opening lacrosse game of the season today, 9 to 2. The contest was played on the lower polo flats in a pouring rain and ankle-deep mud.

Some weeks ago a Richmond letter to THE TIMES described the break-down of the original plans for a commemorative monument at Appomattox, scene of LEE'S surrender to GRANT in 1865. The idea of such a public memorial, decreed by vote of Congress, impressed even the Northern mind a little oddly; for, after all, Appomattox is in Virginia and Virginia was one of the seceding States.

JOE PENNER came on the air with a "duck laugh" and along with several catch expressions he seems to have ensnared many a radio ear. Today he ranks near the top in surveys and popularity polls that measure the effectiveness of comedians at the microphone.

MILAN, March 17, 1934. FAR the most interesting item of the Milanese symphonic season was the concert conducted by Hermann Scherchen, who gave Prokofieff's "Scythian Suite" and Fifth piano concerto, with the composer at the keyboard.

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP). -- Eric Hagenlacher of Germany shot his way back into a tie for first place in the international 18.2 balkline billiard championship tournament today by overcoming Kinrey Matsuyama of Japan, 400 to 286, in fourteen innings.

John W. Thomason Jr. and the publishers deserve grateful thanks for the fine form in which they have presented one of the most delightful personal narratives in American history. In addition to "The Autobiography of David Crockett," "Colonel Crockett's Texas Exploits" is included.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 29. -- For the last two years Puerto Rico has made cuts in its operating budget of more than $2,000,000 each year. Last year ended with a deficit of $1,100,000, due chiefly to hurricane losses, and budget reductions for the current year were designed to wipe this out.

CLEVELAND, March 31. -- Alvanley Johnston, grand chief of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, and C. Stirling Smith, a banker, were sentenced to one to thirty years in the State penitentiary today as an aftermath of a $10,000,000 bank failure two years ago.

The annual Army Day parade down Fifth Avenue next Saturday afternoon will include 15,000 marchers, representing the regular army, National Guard, Reserve Corps, American and Allied veterans and representatives of patriotic societies, it was estimated yesterday.

MANUFACTURERS are coming to realize more generally the selling power of attractive appearance. In pre-depression days of rising demand good design was considered "arty" by many a hard-headed American business man; it was thought to be a minor part of making and selling.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Productive activity continued to forge ahead last week despite threatened labor difficulties, the Commerce Department's weekly survey of domes-the business said today.

Specimens of needlework and embroideries both old and new will be exhibited in behalf of philanthropic enterprises in the near future. The exhibition, for the benefit of the fund for needly and unemployed architects and draftsmen, has been arranged by members of the Women's Division of the Architects Emergency Committee and will open Tuesday morning at the Hayden Galleries, 450 Park Avenue.

The Eastern racing season is scheduled to get under way tomorrow when the Southern Maryland Agricultural Association starts its twelve day meeting at Bowie. Sessions of the same length will follow at Havre de Grace and Pimlico, the $25,000 added Preakness stakes being scheduled for Pimlico on May 12.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 29. -- Parliament is taking its ten-day Easter recess and the voice of oratory is stilled while the members tell the home folk what has been going on in Ottawa in the past two months.

Large increases in industrial and foreign retirements from the totals of the previous month caused a sharp rise in the amount of bonds called for payment in March before their dates of maturity. The $16.574,000 compared with $3,713.000 in February and $28,347,000 in March, 1933.

TWO magics are reported from Forbidden City of Lhasa. One is the reincarnation of the Dalai Lama, himself a reincarnation of Buddha; the other is the arrival of electric light. Before the Dalai Lama died and was reincarnated there existed, under date of the "21st of the Fourth Month of the Water Bird Year," an order, on a large sheet of rice paper, for the arc-light and incandescent bulb equipment, now being set up.

BERLIN, March 30. -- The "back to the land" slogan, which has become a recurring motif in Nazi social legislation, has found reiteration and new variation in a law just promulgated by the Prussian Ministry.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 31. -- Resuming where he left off in last year's final, when he defeated Jack Toomer of Florida, George T. Dunlap Jr., national amateur titleholder, won the qualifying medal in the thirty-fourth annual North and South amateur golf championship today with a 67, four under par.

MARC CONNELLY, who has been more or less inactive since "The Green Pastures" opened, is now collaborating on a play. It is Frank B. Elser's "Low Bridge," which has been tried out in a good many places in the last year or so.

Spring does have a way of atoning for the unhappiness of Winter. It purges both city and country. It is already beginning to atone in the country for a wearisome season by presences not of idle imaginings. The very air needs not tell whence it comes.

TOKYO, March 31. -- The economic development of Manchukuo is to follow the lines of State capitalism instead of State socialism, as the young officers of the Japanese Kwantung general staff planned when the new State was established.

THE farm population of the United States reached an all-time peak of 32,509,000 on Jan. 1, according to the annual estimate just completed by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. But the general city-to-farm movement that set in with the depression was reversed in 1933 the gain of 267,000 during the year being due to a 494,000 surplus of farm births over deaths.

BOSTON, March 31. -- A sailor ashore may regard the ladies with favor, but afloat -- well, that is another story. Every mariner of any standing at all knows that to ship a woman aboard a sailing craft is to sign on bad luck for the voyage.

FOR years the astronomers of California have been talking and dreaming of a reflecting telescope which would have twice the diameter of the famous Mount Wilson 100-inch concave astronomical mirror, at present the largest in the world.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C. -- The season at Southern Pines is now nearing its height and each day brings an influx of Northern visitors who would join in a round of golf or ride the scenic bridle trails of Weymouth Heights. Plans have been made to care for the largest crowd of visitors since 1929, who are expected to attend the Spring festival and sports events next week.

THIS second book of poems by David McCord proves the poet completely at home in his medium. With perfect simplicity of manner, a beautiful technique, individuality of phrase and image, Mr. McCord's lyrics, sonnets and his longer narrative are all in their way perfect.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Match play in the thirty-third annual North and South amateur golf championship will occupy the sports spotlight here this week. The tournament holds unusual interest this year because in it George T. Dunlap Jr., national amateur golf champion, is making his first major start of the year in a match play event.

PARIS, March 23. -- Reform of the covenant of the League of Nations, a study of the fundamental principles of the community of States and the question of international guarantees for individual liberties will be among the problems that will be examined in 1934 by the International Diplomatic Academy in Paris.
The William Rockhill Nelson Gallery of Art in Kansas City, Mo., has purchased a "Portrait of a Lady" by John Singleton Copley from the Newhouse Galleries, according to an announcement here yesterday.

POLITICIANS are prone, it is said, to take a hand in the affairs of the public schools. But school teachers seldom take a conspicuous stand in politics. This week, however, one school man has made the newspaper front pages on a political issue.

TOKYO, Sunday, April 1. -- The melodramatic details of a plot to assassinate Kisaburo Suzuki, President of the Seiyukai, and Ichiro Hatoyama, former Minister of Education, were released last night as seven young reactionaries were indicted.
YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, March 31. -- Tom Cox Lloyd, engineering professor at Anitoch College, recalled today the formula for fixing the date of Easter.

After many years of playing the "golden goose" to a host of ungrateful relatives, Roger Hilliard permits himself the luxury of telling them exactly what he thinks of them and of announcing that he is about to make a new will, leaving his entire estate, with the exception of a few bequests so small as to be insulting, to his second wife.

It is not often that justice and expediency are so combined as they are in the new movement to improve the International Copyright situation by ratifying the Treaty of Rome which the President has sent to the Senate. In the matter of justice, it repeals the onerous clauses compelling manufacture of British books in this country, together with the clause forbidding importation of the original edition of books so copyrighted.

RECORDED in this column on Jan. 14 were the results of some experiments conducted by Drs. Dufton and Bedford on behalf of the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research and the Medical Research Council of England.

LONDON, March 24. -- Public opinion, in Great Britain at least, has arrived at the conclusion that nothing definite can come from the exchange of notes on disarmament between the governments interested. The experts themselves, though usually they despise the opinion of the common herd, are inclined to accept this time the popular judgment.

THE author's admirable faculty clarifying statements of scientific technic make this little book of explanation of some of the recent marvelous achievements of electricity one that any layman of ordinary intelligence can enjoy.

Manufacturers and distributers who have used their codes to impose rigid mark-up provisions and to outline the distributive channels through which goods must move to consumers are encouraging the growth of a new form of major competition, the consumer cooperative movement, George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, warned here yesterday.

VIENNA, March 31. -- Thanks to the many inspired press articles explaining the Constitution the autocratic minority is drawing up, the final product will contain few surprises for Austrians, but it will not be ready for Easter. It will be the first Constitution drawn up on the basis of a Vatican encyclical.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 31. -- The New Jersey mosquito that multiplied tremendously in 1933 to stage something in the nature of a comeback will face new obstacles this year in its perennial struggle against unpopularity.

Various philanthropic organizations in New York are cooperating in behalf of an elaborate entertainment to be held the night of April 15 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the British Great War Veterans of America. Musical, theatrical and radio stars will take part in the program.

Trading was resumed yesterday in the security and grain markets throughout the country, but most of the commodity exchanges remained closed. Foreign markets are closed until Tuesday. Bonds here were steady. Stocks advanced fractionally after an irregular opening, but closed the day stronger.

The possibility that the common shares of general management investment trusts which have senior capital ahead of them may become an attractive medium for participation in the securities market as a result of the passage of a bill for regulation of Stock Exchanges has been discussed in the financial community in the last week.

BUENOS AIRES, March 31. -- The police have begun an investigation of what appears to be a well-organized anti-Semitic campaign here. They have arrested six men and boys accused of complicity in the explosion of three small but noisy bombs in a synagogue yesterday evening, breaking up a religious service at which about 700 persons were present.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP). -- The third quarter of the fiscal year ended today with emergency expenditures still keeping to levels far below those officially forecast by the administration, in submitting the budget to Congress.

Retail trade last week advanced to a striking lead over 1933 throughout the country, with the exception of the Central Northern States, which were blanketed by renewed snowfalls. Dollar sales were estimated to be 35 to 50 per cent higher than in 1933 in many sections of the country.

PARIS, March 31. -- Premier Gaston Doumergue's somewhat heterogeneous Cabinet is face to face with real problems, and it says a great deal for its members that so far none of them has threatened to bolt.
HAVANA, March 31 (AP). -- A former secret policeman under former President Machado was gravely wounded today in a wild shooting affray in the lobby of the Cuban Telephone Company Building.

The North American Company has fulfilled its contingent obligation, due as of today, to underwrite offerings of common stock of the North American Light and Power Company, an affiliate, made theoretically by the latter to its stockholders. This action called for $2,000,000.

ISTANBUL, March 31. -- Three nations began a diplomatic battle today over Samuel Insull, who remained a virtual prisoner tonight aboard the Greek tramp steamer Maiotis, anchored in the middle of the Bosporus.
Defeated in their drive for union recognition, the striking taxi-drivers called off their three-week-old strike yesterday afternoon, and virtually all of them returned to work last night.

PALM BEACH, -- With the coming of Spring days, the many colonists remaining here are planning no large events but settling down to a less feverish tempo than that of the past four months which culminated last week in many parties given for the school and college set.

PROBABILITY that America may soon see cars produced in this country with engines mounted in the rear has had the effect of renewing debate among engineers as to the advantages, if any, that such a change has to offer.

IN abandoning Civil Works and embarking upon his new tripartite policy, the President has abandoned a tentative program of relief for a quasi-permanent one. I say quasi, for it is believed that the new program holds greater possibilities than did the old of aiding those now on relief to regain a foothold in the economic order.

BERLIN, March 31. -- After 230 years of publication the newspaper Vossische Zeitung terminated its existence today. It took its departure from its long fighting career with a valedictory that, however tame in comparison with some of its scorching editorials of the past, for the first time at least hinted at some of the evils under which the German press is laboring as a result of the Nazi regime.

FOR fully twenty years the Mellon Institute of the University of Pittsburgh has made the city smoke problem one of its major concerns. It has drawn so alarming and yet so true a picture of the cost of smoke in health, laundry and paint that the ordinances of many industrial cities impose penalties for excessive smokiness.

The prediction of Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, and other commentators, that there will be government ownership of railroads is contradicted in the current issue of Railway Age, the authoritative publication of the railroad industry.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Hubbard Gold Medal, highest award of the National Geographic Society for exploration and geographic attainments, was presented today to Anne Morrow Lindbergh in recognition of her achievements as copilot and radio operator during the 40,000 miles of flight over five continents and the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Creation of a national board of adjustment for the compulsory settlement of disputes between the railroads and their workers was proposed today by Joseph B. Eastman, transportation coordinator, in a letter to Chairman Rayburn of the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

EVERY week sees emigrants leaving the United States for Europe and elsewhere. Eighty thousand of our foreign-born went back to their lands of origin in the fiscal year ended June 30, outnumbering immigrants for the second year in succession.

The various aspects of America's economic future, as outlined recently by Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace in his pamphlet "America Must Choose," were discussed in the national farm-and-home-hour broadcast over a WJZ-National Broadcasting Company chain yesterday by Raymond Leslie Buell, president of the Foreign Policy Association; James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, and Dr. Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board.

POLITICAL observers, when they mention the "strong men" of President Roosevelt's administration, always include Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, Administrator of the Petroleum Industry and Public Works Administrator. Mr. Ickes leads three vital divisions in the national drive for recovery; he directs the largest public-works fund in history, guides an immense new program of resource conservation, and is accounted, in general, an invaluable asset to the credit of the President who discovered him.

AN experiment designed "to strengthen the practical and social value of music in community life" is now being conducted at the Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow Street, under the auspices of the music division of the Civil Works Administration, of which Mrs. Frances McFarland is director for the metropolitan area.

PARIS, March 21. -- Military tribunals in France are still hearing numerous cases growing out of incidents of the World War, and in particular are being asked to review numerous cases of soldiers who were summarily shot by court-martial.

Eugene H. Lehman, president of the Westchester Council of Utility Rate Committees and former Mayor of Tarrytown sent a letter to Governor Lehman yesterday endorsing the appeal of Louis Waldman, State Chairman of the Socialist party, for immediate appointment of a joint legislative committee to investigate the public utility lobby at Albany.

LONDON, March 31. -- With the coming of the third Easter since the beginning of the world's disarmament conference, better days seem to be in store for the munitions makers. That fact was strikingly emphasized by revelations at the annual meetings of the stockholders of the two chief British armament concerns, held in this present Holy Week.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31. -- The 1934 model of the Yankees was on exhibition at Waterfront Park today against the Newark Bears, and the team returned to the winning column for the first time in a week. Not without a struggle, however, did the McCarthymen down the Ruppert organization's junior varsity.
SAN PEDRO, Calif., March 31 (AP). -- The United States fleet is making ready to fight its way through 4,000 miles of "enemy infested" seas.

DENVER, Col., March 27. -- Crystallized by a deep-sealed feeling, whether justified or not, that the West is being discriminated against in the New Deal, a new political entity is taking form. The States of Montana, Idaho. Wyoming. Nevada, Utah, Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, Western Kansas and Nebraska and possibly the Dakotas, are rapidly being knit into a political unit which ultimately may present as solid a front as did the "Solid South."

The days when the metropolis was still Little Old New York provide a ripe background for Guy Gilpatric's latest collection of short stories. Streets were lined with brownstone front houses. Traffic was made up of hansom cabs, private carriages, prize brewery teams, a few rare and unreliable automobiles and fleets of bicycle riders -- such as the New Amsterdam Wheelmen -- carefully avoiding the cobbled streets.

VATICAN CITY, March 31 (AP). -- Another saint will be recognized and Pope Pius XI will appear before thousands of devoted followers tomorrow as Rome observes Easter Sunday. The Pope will appear in St. Peter's Plaza in a pontificial procession as part of the ceremonies for the canonization of Don Giovanni Bosco, celebrated social service worker of the nineteenth century.

DUBLIN, March 30. -- The political situation of the Irish Free State is an enigma. If a general election were held tomorrow, no one could say with any degree of certainty how the big parties led by Eamon de Valera and General Owen O'Duffy, respectively, would be likely to fare.

LIMA, Peru, March 24. -- All Peru joined yesterday in beginning the celebration of the fourth centenary of the investment of Cuzco, capital city of the Incas, by Pizarro. For weeks 1,000 Indians had been at work restoring the ancient glories of the capital city of their forebears, destroyed or buried by the vandalism of the conquistadores.

The plight of German Jewry, seen in the perspective of Hitlerism's first full year, was the topic of the Passover discourse yesterday in many temples and synagogues throughout the city. A warning that evidences of anti-Semitism were increasing in other parts of Europe and in the United States was recurrent in many of the addresses.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- A charge by the Associated Gas and Electric Company that the Federal Trade Commission had given out information on the alleged Thayer letters, "without explanation or opportunity for explanation," was declared by the commission today to be "at variance with the facts."

THE Lewisohn Stadium concerts will be presented again this season by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. The seventeenth season, which will be the usual eight weeks, will begin on June 26 and end on Aug. 20.

THERE can be no doubt that there is gold in the sea, but the authorities are in dispute as to the quantity. Some say that it varies from 0.01 milligrams per cubic meter in surface and inshore water to as much as 267 milligrams in the deeps.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., March 31. -- On a bleak battleground the touring golf professionals began their last stand of the Winter tour today in the Cavalier open, with Paul Runyan of White Plains, N.Y., and Ky Laffoon of Denver leading the way through the first eighteen holes with 69s.

BEING a singularly perverse little trollop, the theatre refuses to follow the impulses of nature. When gladness and joy are reported to be prevailing through the country the theatre begins to yawn and sulk. Summer being only two or three months away, the chances for a long run look slender, and no one wants to risk a play now that might run a full season if it were produced in September.

DETROIT, March 31. -- A determined effort to obtain permission to furnish Detroit, Flint, Pontiac and other industrial centres in Michigan with natural gas from the State's gas pool is expected when the Michigan Public Utilities Commission begins its hearing on the Industrial Natural Pipe Line Company's application for the right to serve Detroit and other cities in Southeastern Michigan with natural gas.

Nineteen large corporations in St. Louis, including six whose shares are listed on the New York Stock Exchange, have sent telegrams to members of Congress opposing the revised Stock Exchange Control Bill and saying that they would seriously consider withdrawing their securities from listing on stock exchanges if the act as now written should become law.

THIS space having been occupied by comments upon the recently increased output of albums, it seems only fair to mark time here and make mention of a few of the outstanding singles land loose record releases of the Past few weeks.

With the appearance in Northern covers of many of the star performers from the important big circuit trials, together with several of the leading handlers, field trials in the metropolitan district take on an added importance.

Before twenty judges, all singers of the Metropolitan save for Tullio Serafin, the opera conductor, and Arnold Sehoenberg, the composer, with a concert artist, a manager and a critic for representative good measure, the charge of the light brigade of 225 American tenors who for a week past had competed at 584 Fifth Avenue for the prize of a piano and public recognition, ended yesterday in a final hearing and award.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., March 29. -- Upton Sinclair is throwing a scare into each of the major parties in California by the aggressive manner in which he is bidding for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 26. -- The company store, or commissary, which has been an issue before every Alabama Legislature for forty years, is doubly one at this moment. In the Governorship campaign now in progress, two of the three candidates, former Governor Bibb Graves and Judge Leon McCord, have pledged themselves to oppose the issuance to employes by industrial companies of non-negotiable scrip good only at their commissaries.

DRESSMAKERS' needles are busy silver shafts darting through pristine fabrics making ready for Spring brides. It has been some time since they were so diligent in a grand way. Perhaps there are no more brides -- we are not statistically minded -- but weddings are getting more dressy, old family laces are being taken out of vaults, and many bolts of shimmering satin will be consumed before April and May draw to a close.

BOSTON, March 31 (AP). -- Mary Pickford today was the defendant in a New York court action brought by J. Raymond Cornell, retired Wellesley organ manufacturer, as the outcome of a series of mysterious circumstances which occurred during a recent stage engagement of Miss Pickford in Boston.
In an article by J.J. Hayes it is implied that Eugene O'Neill's play, "Days Without End," is to be produced at the Abbey on account of a shortage of native plays. This is not a fact.

SAN LUIS POTOSI, Mexico, whose ore-paved streets are being torn up to obtain the gold and silver embedded in them, is in the centre of a rich mining district. West of Tampico and north of Mexico, D.F., it is located about halfway between the Pacific and the Gulf of Mexico.

RECENT paintings by Mark Datz, the current exhibitor at the Eighth Street Gallery (until April 17), compare favorably with his better-known watercolors. An unmistakable and unashamed lyricism characterizes the work.

PARIS, March 29. -- Paris is reviving enameled bijouteric. A diamond studded, rose enamel shell, containing a huge single pearl, is the latest corsage ornament. A flat halfmoon shaped vanity, in night-blue enamel studded with diamond stars, is used in place of an evening bag.

HAVANA, -- The St. Petersburg Havana Yacht Race, which just started, is holding first place in the interest of both residents and visitors here and the majority of social affairs of the week will centre around this event.

Decided increases in consumer buying in all store departments featured the conclusion of pre-Easter shopping during the week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. Mail and wire orders continued to arrive for merchandise for Easter selling, although in the majority of cases timely deliveries on desirable goods proved uncertain.

UNITED MOTORS SERVICE, INC., General Motors subsidiary, started last Wednesday, at a conference in the Hotel Park Central, a campaign to develop the service business of its affiliated units, including Delco-Remy, AC, Delco-Lovejoy, Klaxon, Harrison and other products.

THE railway workers whose representatives have been negotiating for higher wages with railroad executives and administration officials compose an important section of organized American labor. The parleys have been carried on by the Railway Labor Executives Association, consisting generally of the chief executives of the twenty-one standard unions of railway workers.

THE schools of North Carolina are operating on a third less funds than they spent four years ago and under a more highly centralized educational authority than they have ever known. The changes were made by the State's General Assembly.

TOMBSTONE is coming back to life. An old inhabitant once pronounced its obituary, saying: "It was born a mining town, lived a mining town and died a mining town." But it seems that Tombstone did not quite die. Fifty years ago the livest spot in Arizona, if not in the whole West, and forty years ago almost forgotten, the place is now sitting up and enjoying the prospect of a share of the national recovery.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 31. -- Despite the ascendency of women in public and business life there remain plenty of persons who never miss the opportunity of resurrecting that ancient phrase, "Woman's place is in the home." The speaker most frequently is prejudiced, and usually is male.

While stormy weather and low ceilings held all army air mail ships on the ground yesterday after 6 A.M. and caused the cancellation of commercial flying out of Newark after 11:30 A.M., officers of the air lines spent a busy day studying the detailed proposals of the Post-office Department for bids on temporary air mail schedules.

A work from George Washington's library, Robertson's "History of the Reign of the Emperor Charles V." London, 1782, in four autographed volumes, will be offered at auction this week, at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

The growing conviction among some business leaders that the government will be compelled to enforce a reduction in hours and a wage increase in industry was strengthened last week, when it became known that General Johnson had sent a questionnaire to all Code Authorities, asking their stand on the question.

WITH the signing of Pennsylvania's free school act 100 years ago today, two fundamental principles of democracy were established -- first, an educated citizenry is essential to successful self-government, and, second, it is the obligation of the State to provide for the maintenance of an efficient system of public schools for all children.

The Metropolitan Opera Company said and sang its "au revoirs" yesterday as a climax of recent crowded days, during which operas in four languages rounded up a season of which the details are reviewed in another section of this newspaper today.

Nine men and one woman, some of them said by Federal narcotic agents to be members of a gang with a profitable trade in the city and others alleged to have supplied narcotics to actors and actresses as far West as the Pacific Coast, were arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter.

BOTTOMS UP," the combination of melody and fun which was at the Radio City Music Hall last week, is an agreeable surprise, for although the narrative is light and frivolous it nevertheless is one that captures the attention.

SOUTH AMERICA'S opera season is sometimes mentioned as a convenient Summer holiday for the songbirds of the Northern Hemisphere, whose flight beyond the Equator during May, June or July mitigates for many highly civilized republics the rigors of what is then midwinter in those remoter latitudes.

One of the largest and most varied collections of coins together with early newspapers, old postage stamps, a few autographs and numismatic books to be offered at public sale here for some time will be sold next Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons by Thomas L. Elder at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street.
ROME, March 31. -- The commonest criticism heard of last Sunday's general election is that it was too overwhelming to be entirely convincing.

BERLIN, March 22. -- For reasons unfathomable by the outsider the shoulder-belt is claimed as one of the sacred symbols of National Socialism. Its display by any but simon-pure registered supporters of Nazidom is forbidden in an edict just issued by Herman Wilhelm Goering, who directs the Prussian police to take energetic measures against "unauthorized wearers."

ATLANTA, Ga., March 31. -- Towering over his opponent, Lester Stoefen, the lanky national indoor champion, defeated little Bryan (Bitsy) Grant, ranking No. 7, in straight sets, 7 -- 5, 7 -- 5, 7 -- 5, in the final of the Biltmore invitation tennis tournament today.

GARDENERS who have not enjoyed the advantages of glass-covered hotbeds or cold-frames in which to start seedling plants of vegetables and flowers will welcome the news that there are now available a number of inexpensive substitutes for glass which can be used for this purpose.

Paintings by Watteau, Greuze and Boucher, together with signed pieces of French eighteenth century furniture are included in the collection of the late Mrs. Benjamin Stern, removed from her apartment at 440 Park Avenue and her Roslyn, L.I., home, Claraben Court, which will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- Farm operation is now being conducted at a profit, according to the current review of the Corn Belt Farm Dailies. There is real optimism in the livestock industry, it says. Growers are making money on sheep, are better than breaking even on cattle, and holding their own on hogs, with pork moving into consumption at a decidedly higher price.

THE most spectacular and tragic episode of the Crimean War, the fatal charge of the Light Brigade on Oct. 25, 1854, furnished a mystery which has never been solved; and it is round this mystery that "Trumpeter, Sound!" is written.

BEING filled with outlaws and cut-throats, the town of Monument was thoroughly bad. "They've dressed their town up," said Sheriff Peter Ogden. "but I'll tell you, under that flossy front, this Monument city is as wild as ever any camp in California or Montana; it's as crazy and hot as Abilene or Dodge City ever was in their palmiest days."

WHEN one starts picking out routes on a map one is too easily led into imagining movements and directions," declared Dr. Hubert, discussing Celtic migrations. He was out to discover road maps, and not to make them.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- On an island in Chesapeake Bay, owned by the Jefferson Island Club and to be named Roosevelt Island, a fish ing lodge will be erected for the exclusive use of the President and his guests. This is only a few hours away from Washington.
CHICAGO, March 29. -- The problem of conserving its political hold on Wisconsin is said to be occasioning the La Follette dynasty no little anxious thought.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., March 31. -- Thousands of pilgrims from all sections of the United States were gathering here tonight for the 202d Moravian Easter sunrise service to be held here tomorrow morning at 5:30 o'clock.

NOW and then tidings come from Pitcairn Island, where descendants of the mutineers of H.M.S. Bounty live in isolation. The latest word is that the Bounty's rudder has been retrieved from the ocean depths.
The Most Rev. James DeWolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, Issued this Easter message last night:

VICTORIA, B.C., March 31 (AP). -- Mr. and Mrs. Hiaschuckaluck Cadborosaurus (those sea serpents) returned to their home in Canadian waters in time to celebrate April Fool's Day and Easter, after an enjoyable vacation during which they were reported to have visited the seaside resorts of Oregon and California.

If the open-price principle is to prevail in American industry, it can only do so under government regulations and safeguards that are political in nature and therefore may fail adequately to protect the consumer, representatives of leading retail organizations said here yesterday.
Bruna Castagna, Lucy Monroe, Ralph Errolle and Joseph Royer are announced by Pasquale Amato to sing in "Carmen," which opens a new season at the Hippodrome tomorrow night.

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons are working toward the success of the supper dance and entertainment to be held on April 14 in the ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of Briarcliff Holiday House.

NORFOLK, Va., March 29. -- Virginia, the first of the old Southern Commonwealths to discard its prohibition laws in favor of a new system of liquor control, has passed from a condition of theoretical aridity when liquor was actually abundant to a condition of theoretical abundance when legal liquor is not to be had.

The annual Open House Week of the Kips Bay Boys' Club will start at 4 P.M. tomorrow in its new clubhouse at 301 East Fifty-second Street with a Spring Games Carnival. The winner of top spinning, marble shooting and other contests, according to present plans of the club officials, is to be crowned "King of Spring Games."

A medal, awarded by the Columbia Broadcasting System for outstanding service to radio broadcasting, was presented by proxy to Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd last night in a 9,000-mile short-wave hook-up.

With the arrival of April, nature in the New York area flows with new life and many varieties of creatures which had fled this region for the Winter return, it is pointed out in an announcement released yesterday by the American Museum of Natural History.

Secretary Harold L. Ickes recently announced enlargement of the Dayton, Ohio, homestead project, J which now provides for thirty-five homesteads, to include 165 additional homesteads, a Federal bulletin reports. The program for the development at Dayton is being carried out by the Subsistence Homesteads Division, of which M. L. Wilson is director, with selfhelp being emphasized throughout.

AN infant prodigy is a dangerous subject for fiction writers. A wonder child who at 14, having mastered several Oriental as well as a dozen European tongues, competes in the finals of international chess tournaments may well inspire astonishment; but though we admire his mnemonic prowess and power of concentration we refuse to take him to our hearts.

WITH "On the Rocks" Shaw completes his thirty-seventh play. His early duties with the Edison Telephone Company, his reviewing and practical politics made him a late starter, but he may now say, in his seventy-eighth year, that he has written as many plays as Shakespeare.

Although 30,000 CWA workers will be dropped from the payrolls when the CWA program is transferred today to the Works Division of the Department of Public Welfare, Colonel Walter A. DeLamater, CWA Administrator, expressed the belief yesterday that every worker in actual need would retain his job in the shift.

LONDON, March 31. -- The British Government completed its financial year tonight with the proud announcement that it had a surplus of about 31,148,000, an achievement probably unmatched by any country since the world-wide depression began.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- The Montreal Maroons will skate onto the ice at the Chicago Stadium tomorrow night to make one last, desperate effort to keep Canada in the battle for the Stanley Cup, the old trophy that means the world's professional hockey championship.

AMONG the things men do not know about mankind is the identity, derivation and language of the civilized, artistic, luxurious inhabitants of Etruria in West Central Italy northwest of the Tiber, conquered by Rome in 283 B.C.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Civil Works Administration went cut of existence today, and this relief organization became the Works Division of the Federal Emergency Relief Administration.

Attempts have been made from time to time to complete Charles Dickens's unfinished novel. "The Mystery of Edwin Drood," and to discover how Dickens intended the story to end. In "Epilogue," Bruce Graeme transports two twentieth century Scotland Yard detectives back to the time of "Edwin Drood" and has them solve the mystery by modern methods, in so far as those methods are applicable to the time in which they find themselves.

WHEN two pieces of dough are kneaded together they become indistinguishably one. Howard J. Burnish, electrochemist and steel mill designer, has devised a process which does the same for steel. Examine two lengths of steel pipe welded together by his method and even the microscope cannot reveal a seam.

BOSTON, March 31 (AP). -- The Providence Reds put on a vicious third-period attack to open the Fontaine Cup series for the Canadian-American Hockey League championship with a 4-1 victory over the Boston Cubs, last year's titlists, before 12,000 tonight at the Boston Garden.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 31. -- Russell Sturgis Hepburn, 21 years old, a Harvard junior, shot himself to death early this morning on a bank of the Charles River near the Stillman Infirmary.

HOUSTON, Texas, March 29. -- It begins to look as if former Governor James E. Ferguson put over a fast one when he had the Democratic State Committee, which he controls, name him to succeed Jed Adams as the Texas member of the Democratic National Committee.

MIAMI, Fla., March 31. -- The seventy-nine-day Florida racing season was brought to a successful conclusion today as Frank A. Carreaud's Sea Fox raced to victory in the mile of the Nourmahal Handicap, feature of the final program at Tropical Park.

Shedding their professional manner with their raincoats, twoscore New York physicians elbowed their way last night into the Academy of Medicine for the opening of the seventh annual exhibition of the New York Physicians Art Club.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 21. -- The Princeton rugby team scored an 8-0 victory over the French Rugby Club of New York on a rain-soaked field today. Bill Halton, playing at left three-quarters for the Tigers, scored all of Princeton's points on a penalty kick, a try and a conversion.
From sheer gratitude I am moved to write to some one of the thrill of hearing the Metropolitan Grand Opera in the middle of the Pacific.

The first in the series of Dolphin Dances for future debutantes took place last night in the grand ballroom of the Pierre. It was one of the largest Easter parties of the season for younger members of society at home from schools and colleges for the holidays.

Awaking after the wildest party of his wild young life, Lester Wilton learned that immediate retirement from the city is indicated if he is to preserve his peace of mind and his state of single blessedness, if, indeed, the latter has not already gone by the board.

THE recent exchange of good-will messages between Foreign Minister Hirota and Secretary Hull is expected to result in a more auspicious approach toward the settlement of outstanding Japanese-American issues. The two men concurred in the declaration that, broadly viewed, no question existed between their countries "fundamentally incapable of amicable solution."

As a reader of your editorial page with all the regularity in my power, I am ordinarily content to enjoy, with no comment. I am moved, however, to write briefly, with a question, and with a very slight comment.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March 31. -- More than 1,500 municipal employes, including school teachers and police and firemen, failed to get their pay today. Controller John Lynn insisted that the payment was due, but Mayor Leslie V. Bateman said the paychecks were not due until next week. The payroll totaled $160,000.

Local retail trade rose last week to the best level of the year to date as Easter shopping expanded under favorable weather conditions. Consumer demand covered a broad array of merchandise and indications are that leading stores will report a gain in dollar sales volume of more than 35 per cent over the same period a year ago.

PIERRE, S.D., March 29. -- Recognition of the theory that American agriculture has not learned to handle its mixed prairies properly is giving strength to a new farm viewpoint and causing sharp discussion of the AAA plan to remove unprofitable lands from cultivation.

THIS is the story of a brave girl's fight to save her brother, who is in prison, convicted of murder. So far as the police are concerned, the case is closed, and the only way in which Margot Ross can obtain her brother's release is by proving that some one else committed the crime of which he has been convicted.

Younger members of society are taking an active interest in the plans for the Easter ball to be held Wednesday night in the Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Frontier Nursing Service. Miss Lois Swan heads the dance committee and her aides are the Misses Jeanne Millet, Camilla Morgan, Jean Harder, Eileen Gillespie, Eulalie Ashmore, Florence St. John Wilder, Angela Fowler, Camilla Moss and Virginia Hoyt.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 31. -- Professor Clemente Pereda, hunger striker against the legislative move for statehood, broke his week's fast today and was removed to a hospital where his condition is said to be fair, according to Dr. Octavio Jordan.

MIAMI, -- Miami's official celebration of Pan-American Day on April 14 will honor Cuba and is to be featured by the presentation that night in Bayfront Park of a pageant entitled "Cuba Libre," especially written for the occasion by Dr. Barbara Ring of Miami and Boston.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31. -- As a departure from the comparative quiet of Holy Week there are many large parties for Easter week-end and many of these took place today.

WHITE PLAINS, March 31. -- Although the Westchester County CWA bureau officially passed out of existence this afternoon, there will be no material layoff of men at this time, it was announced by Wayne Heydecker, director of the Westchester emergency work bureau and former head of CWA work in the county.

WHILE Tiffany Thayer painted sensational pictures of more or less familiar monstrosities and violences, it was captious to accuse him of improbability. His exaggerations, his melodrama and his awful overtones were the Chamber of Horrors of a waxworks museum.

BREMERTON, Wash., March 31 (AP). -- A grim tragedy, the shooting to death of six persons after they had been bound and gagged, was discovered late today at the beach home of Frank Flieder, well-to-do retired grocery store operator.

Industrial conditions continued to improve throughout the country last month, according to the report made public yesterday by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. Despite the gains in business activity, purchasing agents have reverted to their former practice of buying materials only for immediate needs.

SOME New Yorkers who recall the Metropolitan's grand opera comedians in "Schwanda the Bagpiper," with a gayety not often Associated with German opera here, will read with approval an account from the Central European Observer concerning "A Bed of Roses," Jaromir Weinberger's new musical comedy, the Prague premiere of which recently took place at the Velka Opereta. The comedy had its first performance at Brno.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31. -- A classification of terrestrial animals on the basis of energy rather than of form or structure was proposed the American Association of Anatomists here today by Dr. George Crile of the Cleveland Clinic.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 31 (AP). -- Fearful that he might have to undergo an operation for the removal of his appendix, Mickey Cochrane, manager of the Detroit Tigers, returned to the team's training headquarters at Lakeland, Fla., tonight.

Two men, who pretended they had a package to deliver, bound a maid and an elevator operator in the apartment of Mrs. Marie A. Lasher at 77 Park Avenue shortly after 9 A.M. yesterday and escaped with a string of pearls and other articles, valued by the police at more than $10,000.

A SYSTEM of educating young drivers has been adopted in Superior, Wis., according to a report made by Thomas Allen of the Superior Police Department to Public Safety, publication of the National Safety Council.
Vicki Baum has been engaged by Samuel Goldwyn to write a story for Anna Sten's next picture, following "Resurrection," which is now in production.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1. -- More than 1,000 daily newspapers of this country have been entered in the fourth exhibition of newspaper typography to be held in the Ayer Galleries here beginning Thursday and continuing until June.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, in an Easter sermon yesterday morning joined with Cardinal Hayes and Bishop Manning in their recent denunciation of what the Cardinal in his pastoral letter on the subject called "nasty" current publications.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Bright sunshine brought thousands of visitors here for Easter who thronged the churches and joined the Capital residents in the greatest Sunday parade witnessed in several years.

Harlem had its own Easter parade yesterday. It was a sinuous, brilliant procession of hundreds of chanting followers of the Rev. M.J. Divine, who is "Father" to thousands of Negroes in a series of "kingdoms" throughout the metropolitan area.

LONDON, March 31. -- After a period of quite remarkable stability, renewed unsettlement and weakness in the exchanges are again apparent. Fears are once more being expressed concerning the ability of Continental European countries to remain on the gold standard.

Forty American scholars, research workers and creative artists have been selected to receive the tenth annual fellowship awards of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, April 1. -- The budget surplus of 31,148,000 has not in the least altered Great Britain's determination not to pay another instalment on her debt to the United States.

Commodity prices worked higher last week, but showed erratic movements throughout the four days of trading which ended on Thursday. Silver and silk alone showed lower prices at the close of the week in the futures markets, while the spot markets were weak, as a rule.

DUBLIN, April 1. -- Parades were held throughout the Irish Free State today to commemorate the republican insurrection of 1916. Parades were planned in Northern Ireland but the Belfast Government issued an order banning all republican Easter demonstrations.

Total sales of $112,671,770 are reported for the fiscal year ended Jan. 27, 1934, by R.H. Mary Co., Inc., and affiliated stores, comparing with $118,879,252 for the previous fiscal year. The other stores are L. Bamberger Co. in Newark, N.J.; the Davison-Paxon Company in Atlanta, Ga., and the Lasalle Koch Company in Toledo, Ohio.

Unless further delay occurs in getting the money that is to be advanced by the British Government for completion of the 73-000-ton Cunarder 534 in the shipyard at Clydebank, Glasgow, it is expected that 1,000 men will be put to work tomorrow morning.

City College foilsmen were facing the favored Navy team in the deciding match for the Iron Man Trophy just before midnight on Friday. To the winner would go the oldest prize in intercollegiate sport, a trophy which has been at stake throughout the forty-one years of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association.

NEW ORLEANS, April 1. -- Inserting one sharp, decisive thrust into the pitching of Oral Hildebrand in the second inning, the Giants today gave the Indians a comprehensive demonstration of how a National League pennant and world's championship was won last year through a remarkable system of defensive play evolved by Memphis Bill Terry.

Workers under the CWA in this State received about $80,000,000 from the Federal Government in wages between last November and last Saturday, when the CWA as such was demobilized and its function transferred back to the work relief groups of the State and city.

ST. LOUIS, April 1. -- The champion Stix, Baer and Fuller Soccer Club successfully began the defense of its title today. The local eleven turned back the Pawtucket Ranger in the opener of the three-game national challenge cup series, scoring in a hard-fought overtime battle 4 -- 2, as 10,000 looked on.

MOBILE, Ala., April 1. -- Thomas A. Hart, 45 years old, a social service worker formerly of New York and until recently an official of the Mobile Transient Bureau, was found shot to death early today in an alley near the business district.

AMSTERDAM, March 30. -- The latest developments in the situation in the United States, the sudden arising of acute labor disputes, were entirely expected here. Belief has been firm all along that the labor situation was now the foremost consideration in the movement of recovery.
