ALBANY, April 13. -- A series of rapid-fire developments came late today on Capitol Hill in the public utility situation.
Baseball will have its unofficial opening here today when the 1934 edition of the New York Yankees opposes the Brooklyn Dodgers at the Yankee Stadium. The game is scheduled to start at 3 o'clock.

HARTFORD, April 12. -- Connecticut's comparative freedom from labor troubles appears to have become a thing of the past in the face of a strong aggressive stand by or-organized labor immediately after a mass effort by the manufacturers of the State to align the State's delegation in Congress against pending New Deal legislation.

THIS narrative poem, written, really, as a series of shorter poems, starts well. The first poem, "The Lauds of the Gadgets," is a very good piece of satirical writing. But Miss Converse soon gets emotional about her thesis. And her thesis is a bit confusing.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., April 14. -- Rowing on Community Lake today, Choate's first and second fours defeated two informal Princeton fours over a five-eighths of a mile course. The crews were handicapped by a strong headwind that made fast times impossible.
PARIS, April 14. -- The French Ministry of Commerce today announced the restoration of minimum tariffs on American brushes, which had been placed under the general rates by an earlier decree.

His Excellency the United States Ambassador in Berlin having gone home on leave, this seems to be an appropriate season for writing about him. Being on a holiday, he will probably never see this writing. If he does he will probably have forgotten all about it by the time he returns.

IN the Brooklyn Museum, until May 6, the twenty-first annual exhibition of the Allied Artists of America and the sixteenth annual exhibition of the Brooklyn Society of Miniature Painters are current, along with the material assembled in honor of the borough's centennial.

The annual Boys' Club of New York play contest, sponsored by the Theatre Guild, will begin this week, with preliminary competitions being held every night from tomorrow through Friday at various clubhouses throughout the city. The winners in these contests will meet on Monday evening, April 30, in the Y.M.H.A. auditorium, at Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

BERLIN, April 14. -- Today's session of the Boerse repeated yesterday's dullness in a more pronounced form, with transactions reduced to small proportions. Spasmodic changes upward or downward ranging from fractions to 2 points and more were without any general market significance.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., April 12. -- The so-called "rainy season" in Southern California is about over. Rain means more in this part of the world than almost anywhere else, because from November to April enough moisture must be stored in natural underground pools and in artificial above-ground reservoirs to provide man and beast and fruits and flowers with water enough to insure sustenance, propagation and protection during the six months when the skies are dry.

WHAT was the nature of the seed from which the antislavery movement grew? Who planted it and watched and fostered its growth? Were moral indignation and purpose or economic causes responsible for its origin and development?

PINEHURST, N.C., April 14. -- In brilliant contest of fifty games that consumed two and one-half hours, Francis X. Shields of New York, the No. 1 ranking player of the country, checked the opposition of Wilmer Allison of Austin, Texas, ranked No. 2, to win the sixteenth annual North and South tennis championship today, 10 -- 8, 14 -- 12, 6 -- 0.
I am just as keen as the average fan for the opening of this particular baseball season -- the fifty-ninth, by the way, of my league.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 14. -- Syracuse rallied strongly to defeat the Army lacrosse team, 8 to 7, in a game played in the rain today. A goal scored in the last ten seconds of an extra period enabled the visitors to down the Cadets after a thrilling battle.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 14. -- Election of officers by fourteen fraternities and local clubs at Rutgers was announced today by William H. Rheinheimer, president of Interfraternity Council. Those named to chapter posts are:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 14, -- The Garden Day Committee of the Westchester County Children's Association has chosen the list of hostesses for the gardens to be open in the series and for the sale of tickets for the two lectures which will supplement the garden visits this year.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Condemnation through Federal courts of property desired by the Federal Emergency Housing Corporation for slum clearance and low-cost housing projects will be used in the future against obstructive property owners, Secretary Ickes announced today.

The problem of liquor control is the problem of the people, upon whom depends the successful passage and administration of good liquor laws, Mrs. John S. Sheppard, member of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, said last night.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP). -- Wage differentials proposed for the oil industry by its Code Authority were disapproved today by the Petroleum Labor Policy Board, but a union leader said the victory was "only negative" and that a nation-wide strike vote would proceed.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 14. -- Eight alumni and faculty members of Princeton University will file petitions this week for entrance into the Mercer County primary elections to be held on May 15, it was learned here today. They will run for national, State and municipal offices.

IN the farcical manoeuvres of "You're Telling Me," the cinematic work displayed at the Paramount last week, W.C. Fields does some exceptionally clever acting and it is therefore a pity that he is given at times to spoiling his fun by being repetitious.

FEW Winters have passed with the air as clear of after-dinner speeches as the 1933-34 season. There was a day when broadcasters thrived on banquet orators. They eased the task of the program planners who had free time on their hands.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 14. -- The Princeton Prep baseball team defeated the Princeton Freshman nine, 4 -- 3, in the Tiger Cubs' opening game on Brokaw Field today. Bob Robertshaw, the Prep's left-handed pitcher, held the losers to five hits.
CINCINNATI, April 14 (AP). -- Shaky fielding by the Reds and timely hits by the Tigers gave the American League club a 7-to-6 victory in an exhibition game today.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 14. -- Hallmark, the Irish hunter owned by Miss Frederica Fry of Greenwich, won the championship in the first horse show of the Spring season, concluded tonight at the Round Hill Stables. C.B. Rich's Mallow Boy took the reserve.

CHICAGO, April 14. -- The right of the Federal Agricultural Adjustment Administration to regulate the milk industry by means of set prices at which all milk must be bought from farmers was upheld in a Federal Court of Equity here today.

Justice Samuel D. Levy of Children's Court told 200 public and parochial school teachers yesterday that if fifteen minutes were devoted each day in their schools to an extra class in moral lessons and character building, far fewer children would appear in his court.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- President Roosevelt tonight signed an executive order providing for approval by General Johnson of all budgets and assessments of Code Authorities for financing the administration of codes.

THE title which Mr. Stowe has attached to his narrative of the lives of his great-grandfather, his grandmother and his granduncles and grandaunts is slightly misleading. It implies, as did the original phrase of Dr. Leonard Bacon, that "this country is inhabited by saints, sinners and Beechers," that the Beechers were at least occasionally sinful, whereas there is nothing in the book to indicate that they ever were.

AMONG those who have the leisure there is a growing tendency to revert to old handicrafts. Because of the time and skill necessary to produce articles by hand, together with the higher cost of materials bought in small quantities, competition with factories as to price is, of course, not possible.

JOHN H. SEGER went down to the Indian country that is now Oklahoma in the middle '70s to help the Indian agent at the Darlington agency carry out a plan to provide civilized living quarters for the Arapahoe Indians in the hope that thus it would be easier to induce them to settle down, send their children to school and learn to live like the whites.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga. -- With Summer weather treading on the heels of a delightful Winter, the, season's visitors and guests are reluctantly approaching the time of their trek northward, to give way to the Summer visitors.

VIENNA, April 14. -- The military plot against King Carol and Mme. Helene Lupescu, the details of which are still obscured, has caused the Rumanians to preen themselves that theirs is one of the few States that have held out against the encroaching wave of fascism.

While Horace E. Dodge has not announced which of his Gold Cup speed boats he plans to take to Italy to race against the 12-litre craft this Summer, he is expected to send the Delphine VI, if he decides upon but one craft. If two, the Delphine VII probably will be added.

Tremendous effort by certain Congressmen, aided and abetted by certain partisan newspapers and others, to make a cause celebre out of the statements of Dr. William A. Wirt regarding the obviously radical tendencies of the so-called "brain trust" has had the fate that was expected.

THIS is Dante that you can take or leave. He stalks through this story of his wanderings with the detachment the artists love to impute to him. (See pictures of Dante, resting on his elbow, staring at Beatrice and the city of Florence; Dante looking at Purgatory, accompanied by Virgil.)

Although the last-minute rush to file tax returns will not come until tomorrow, more than 25,000 filed returns yesterday at the offices of the Department of Taxation and Finance, 80 Centre Street. Large numbers of returns also were reported at the Brooklyn, Bronx and Yonkers offices by Wesley M. Dawson, District Tax Supervisor.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 14. -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has a new dawn patrol of thirty students.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., April 14. -The Most Rev. Thomas J. Walsh, Bishop of Newark, N.J., confirmed his 100,000th child in the Diocese of Newark this afternoon. The ceremony was in St. Joseph's Church here. The child was Phillis Regena Blane, 13 years old, of Maplewood, and she was a member of a confirmation class of 391 girls and boys.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- President Roosevelt today signed the Rankin-Norris resolution recently adopted by Congress directing the Federal Power Commission to investigate and compile the rates for electric energy and its services to residential, rural, commercial and industrial consumers throughout the country.

Benjamin F. Schreiber, president of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association of Washington Heights, announced yesterday that the organization had leased the building at 178th Street and Fort Washington Avenue, on the George Washington Bridge Plaza, from the Port Authority and would occupy it as soon as alterations have been completed.

Eugene C. Pomeroy, prefers fascism to democracy "as it is." Again it is merely a question of definition -- what is mob violence? Were the landed gentry who forced their way into the presence of King John professional agitators and guilty of mob violence?

Democrats seeking to depose John F. Curry as leader of Tammany moved a step nearer their goal last night, when a large majority of the election district captains and County Committee members of the Eighth Assembly District called for the resignation of Solomon Goldenkranz, the district leader.

THE art of life, according to Cranmer-Byng, reached perfection during the T'ang and Sung periods of China and the Ashikaga of Japan. Dealing with Chinese culture during the years from 618 to 1278 A.D., he points out what the Chinese ideal has to offer which Western philosophy does not yet understand.

Here is an old friend in new guise. "The Gardener's Handbook" is a revised and greatly extended version of "The Gardener," one of Dr. Bailey's most popular books. As in the original volume, the arrangement of the subject-matter in this one is by alphabetic sequence, which makes its use as a handbook for reference extremely convenient.

I was reported from London last week that a system of safety zones for pedestrians was to be tested in the more congested parts of the city and that a new road traffic bill provided for special pedestrian crossings and imposed penalties on those who walked dangerously.

THERE are no more receptive targets for the primitive barbs of superstition than those who work in the theatre, be it of the stage or screen. When they are not shuddering in terror at a novitiate's thoughtlessness in whistling in a dressing room, they are stubbornly refusing to go back for a script that has been left behind during rehearsals.

In a day of four opera performances at three theatres by as many rival institutions, announcement was made yesterday of a gift of $40,000 to the Metropolitan by the trustees of the Juilliard Foundation. Lucrezia Bori, chairman of the Committee for Maintaining Metropolitan Opera, disclosed the amount of the gift in addressing, during an intermission, the great audience which attended yesterday's matinee, given in aid of the Metropolitan's guaranty fund.

The World Alliance for International Friendship gave its endorsement yesterday to the position taken by Dr. W. Russell Bowie, rector of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, in his recent sermon attacking indiscriminate benefits to World War veterans.

The scene of "Bright Star" is laid in Corinth, a steel town in Ohio. The author builds her story around the Marsh family, who are cousins to all the best people in town. It is primarily a record of their love affairs, bitter and sweet. The mother, Fluvanna, had lost her husband in a tragic way when her three children were youngsters.
One hour after he was reduced to the rank of captain yesterday morning because of "unsatisfactory" service, Deputy Chief Inspector Thomas F. Walsh applied for retirement from the Police Department.

Aroused by the allegations of a girl student of Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn, which led to the arrest of four boys, also students at the school, three on statutory charges and one on a charge of possessing indecent pictures, the Civic Survey Bureau demanded yesterday an investigation and the abolition of coeducation in the city's public schools.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 14. -- Nepken Carolina Bill, white and black pointer dog, today won the open all-age stake, leading event of the annual Spring meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club. He is owned by Clarence F. Gaines of Sherburne, N.Y., and was handled by George Crangle of Redfield, N.Y.

PORTSMOUTH, England, April 14 -- A new and absorbing chapter in the ancient rivalry between the United States and England for world yachting supremacy will begin Monday with the launching of T.O.M. Sopwith's all-steel Endeavour.

SELDOM is an artist's second exhibition so radically different from his first as in the case of Virginia Berresford. The change and development are all the more notable since each aspect of her work is by itself so distinctive.

With the appearance of the thirteenth volume, the Dictionary of American Biography, published under the auspices of the American Council of Learned Societies, is two-thirds of the way toward its completion. Moreover, the greater part of the material for the remaining seven volumes is now in hand or in active preparation.

School district superintendents and principals are asked in a circular sent out by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, to cooperate with the Health Department in urging parents to have their children between 9 months and 6 years immunized against diphtheria.

THE seventh biennial Harper Prize Novel competition, ending on Feb. 1, 1935, has been announced by Harper Brothers. Sinclair Lewis, Dorothy Canfield and Louis Bromfield will be the judges. Any author who is a citizen of the United States and who has not published a novel in book form prior to Jan. 1, 1921, is eligible to compete for the $7,500 award.

HERE in America, particularly in small suburban gardens, we have too long neglected walls, displaying our gay little "garths" to the world rather than keeping them for the enjoyment of ourselves and our families or for the peaceful rediscovery of our souls during comfortable hours out of doors.
WITH Goya, Elie Faure has penetratingly remarked, "everything is drama, even a portrait." And later, "it is as if he" -- this "sorcerer" of Spain -- "had surprised life itself."

MR. BAERLEIN places Juan Belmonte in a triad with Cervantes and Goya. These three stand for great ages in Spain. Thousands of aficionados would probably say -- unless they were partisans of Joselito -- why drag in the other two?

A uniform system of accounts for high school students' general organizations, which supervise the school lunchrooms, has been instituted by school officials in view of the rapid growth of the organizations to a business with cash receipts of more than $2,000,000 annually.

HAVING been official operator of the guillotine in France for twenty-five years, Anatole Joseph Deibler, now 76, will retire. He has a weak heart and his physician advised him to give up his grim job. His retirement means the end of a family connection with the job of executioner; his father and grandfather served in the office, but Anatole leaves no son.

Ninety per cent of 67,000 New York tenements which serve as shelter for almost 2,000,000 persons are firetraps, according to the Emergency Committee for Tenement Safety, which issued a general report of housing conditions yesterday.
A dapper man, expectant in face and bearing a Gladstone bag, entered a London West End hotel, registered from Tilbury, on the Thames, 20 miles southeast of London, and said:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 14. -- Yale opened its lacrosse season today by turning the varsity loose upon an alumni team for a 10-2 triumph. Crawley, Taylor and J. Warner, who scored two goals apiece for the regulars, featured on the attack, while Captain Train and Barnum were outstanding varsity defensive players. Hill's goal play averted repeated alumni scores.

PARIS. ONCE again it is possible to tell from the front of the gown whether a lady is in formal evening dress or not. This was far from being the case last season, when -- what with dressy long sleeves and muffled throats -- one had to wait for a glimpse of train or an open back for confirmation.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP). -- The government's effort to convict Bishop James Cannon Jr. on an election-law charge was pointed tonight toward the final prosecution testimony of an accountant-investigator.

THE first year of the Roosevelt administration will be long remembered. For it witnessed not only a great change in the tactics of the American Government but a turning-point in the most severe depression through which American capitalism has passed.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14. -- A.A. Chapman, former confidential secretary to Thomas E. Mitten, late head of the Philadelphia Traction System, has brought into court charges against his former employer and the latter's son, Dr. A.A. Mitten, who now is chairman of the board of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company.

ABOARD S.S. EXILONA, off the coast of Greece, Sunday, April 15 (AP). -- Samuel Insull, on his way home to face the courts on fraud charges, is showing anything but dismay at the situation, and for the first time he evidences a disposition to talk.

SPRING being here, rock gardens are breaking into delicate bloom, and hardy perennials with their usual optimism are thrusting up, through gradually drying soil, their many-colored and multi-formed bayonets and banners.

ALBANY, April 14. -- A bill repealing the provision in the State ABC Law under which each licensee is compelled to file a bond, and imposing a surcharge, equal to the prmium on the bond, to be used in defraying the cost of enforcing the Liquor Law, was introduced today in the Legislature by Senator William T. Byrne.

LONDON. IT is of some significance that this year the guest of honor at the annual meeting of the Booksellers' Provident Institution was Sir Richard Gregory. F.R.S. A generation ago the man of science and the bookseller seemed almost to live in different spheres.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Just how "tough a guy" the President is will be demonstrated in his dealings with Congress for the next few weeks. Those Democrats who have been knocking holes in his program and wrecking his economy are growing more and more uneasy as the hour for the demonstration impends.

CLEVELAND, April 14. -- The expected triumphal entry of the Cleveland Indians into their home town, dragging the world's champion Giants at their heels, slipped a cog today when the expedition, completing one of the most arduous exhibition tours ever attempted by two major league clubs, ran full tilt into a baby blizzard and a biting gale.

TOKYO, March 24. -- Japan sometimes seems to act as an economic seismograph, perhaps because her economic structure, being new and hastily run up, reacts quickly to the subterranean waves. The first of the post-war slumps began in Japan in 1920 and spread round the world.

SAN FERNANDO, Trinidad, April 14. -- Shipping in the harbor here was seriously menaced this morning when the 11,000-gallon Trinidad Leaseholds oil barge Pyramid, moored at the jetty with a week's supply of gasoline for the city, exploded at 3:30 A.M., shooting flames skyward.

AN invention which may possibly revolutionize one aspect of violin playing and likewise open certain new possibilities to composers has been perfected in the last few weeks by a young Viennese viola player, Richard Goldner, and has quickly gained the enthusiasm of such musicians as have seen it.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 14. -Though Griff Sexton, Plebe twirler last season, pitched a one-hit game against the University of Virginia today, errors by his mates and passes enabled the Cavaliers to win, 2 to 0.

HOW many women realize that they can dress from tip to toe in garments created from materials whose genesis was in a laboratory? We had little realization of this until a few days ago we happened into the Fashion Group's exhibition of "Man-Made Materials" in its gallery at Rockefeller Center.

The only game which the visiting English lacrosse players are slated to play in the metropolitan district, except for their appearance next month in the national championship, will be held at the Cathedral School of St. Mary's field, Garden City, L.I., on Saturday.

A SCORE for the influence of environment as against heredity appears to be chalked up by Dr. Maller's survey reported on this page today. At any rate, the seemingly inevitable link between neighborhood conditions and the character of New York youth confirms the findings of earlier investigators in other parts of the country.

CORNISHMEN and friends of Cornwall have recently made an appeal to save one of their country's beauty spots, St. Agnes Head and the region surrounding it, from possible exploitation by real estate promoters. It is intended to purchase 640 acres of this area, which will probably be turned over to the National Trust.

THIS volume of adventure and misadventure, the record of a soldier of fortune, sometimes menaces the prestige of Munchausen at his best. Through his medium, Howard Marsh, Mr. Veil tells of his somewhat hectic career, often etched in comic relief, which carried him to a South American ranch, to Paris and the war, to Russia, to opera-bouffe adventures in the Near East and to his present abode, a lonely mine somewhere in the Rockies.

Margaret Turnbull writes both romances and mysteries. In her latest book she combines the two. It begins where most love stories end, with the bride in ivory satin standing before her mirror. But beside her own glowing reflection Nan saw the ratlike face of a little man who knew all the horrid story of the ghastly episode that might turn Alan against her.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- A hard battle between the Senate and House over the upper branch's amendments to the "loophole plugging" tax bill was indicated today as experts started to check up on just what happened to the measure in the Senate.

BALTIMORE, April 14. -- Stuart S. Janney Jr., one of Maryland's finest steeplechase riders, won another brilliant victory with Hotspur II, chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. W. Austin Wadsworth of New York, in the My Lady's Manor point-to-point, feature of four races run today over the estates of Leslie E. Keiffer and J. Myers Pearce in Harford County.

THE piquant combination of a couple of Broadway troupers and an African jungle setting makes "Congo Landing" an exceptionally interesting tale. Dolly, for the moment in the fortune-telling racket, is the life of it. She is a canny and discerning little blonde, who has served her time in carnivals, vaudeville and music halls.

BOSTON, April 14 (AP). -- The Boston Red Sox uncorked their first real punch of the Spring today when they bombarded Ben Cantwell and Leo Mangum for a total of thirteen hits and gained their first victory in four starts against the Boston Braves, 8 -- 2.

Playing against seventeen opponents in an exhibition of simultaneous play at the National City Bank Chess Club yesterday, Israel A. Horowitz of the Manhattan Chess Club won fifteen of the games, and drew the other two.

NINE hundred Germans live huddled together in the outskirts of Paris in what is known as "Les Bastions," the great forbidding graystone barracks formerly occupied by French troops, but now given by the government for the use of these refugees.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 10. -- The spectacle of two retired major generals in the front-line trenches of a political primary battle, one seeking the nomination for Governor on the Democratic ticket and the other the same place on the Republican, will give Oregonians an added interest in the election campaign that will end May 18.

LONDON, April 14. -- Norman H. Davis, chief of the United States delegation to the disarmament conference, sailed for New York on the Berengaria today after several weeks in Europe which he insisted had been devoted entirely to private legal work connected with Kreuger litigation.

Many devotees of "second nature" will be a little puffed up by the observations of Dr. FIESSINGER of Paris in Journal des Practiciens in praise of Habit. It is a great economy for the nervous system. It says to the brain: "Ground arms!" It prevents waste of thought about initiative:

Forecasts on the chances of their clubs in the pennant races were made yesterday for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the managers of the local clubs. The statements of Bill Terry of the Giants, Joe McCarthy of the Yankees and Casey Stengel of the Dodgers follow:

In spite of the protest of many Baptists in the United States, the fifth meeting of the Baptist World Alliance will be held in Germany from Aug. 4 to 10 unless an unforeseen contingency arises, according to a statement from the three highest officers of the alliance received here from the headquarters in London.

There will be several visiting clergymen in the pulpits of Manhattan today, including at least two from abroad. "Salvation Army Sunday" will be marked by pleas in behalf of the current citizens' appeal for the work of the Army. In all Catholic churches the pastoral letter will be read from Cardinal Hayes telling of the annual Catholic charities appeal, to begin April 22 and continuing for a week.

Generally improved economic conditions, rehabilitation of the South and the growth of home sewing are among the factors expected to make National Cotton Week, starting on May 14, the most successful yet held. More than 30,000 stores throughout the country will join in observing the promotion, as compared with a total of about 28,000 last year.

NEW ORLEANS, April 14. -- A Federal court of appeals dissolved today an interlocutory injunction issued against an agency of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, and in its opinion described the AAA marketing agreement for Florida citrus growers as being "legal."

WHEN, several years ago, two of the larger record companies presented a collection of disks to the New York Public Library they probably did not realize that they were helping to establish a sort of experimental laboratory.

More than 1,000 former CWA workers milled around the Bronx CWA and Home Relief headquarters at Webster Avenue and 188th Street yesterday morning, protesting against recent lay-offs. Three were arrested and charged with disorderly conduct when the crowd stormed the building.

AMHERST, Mass., April 14. -- Amherst students' dramatic taste is varied. "Hamlet" will soon be offered by the Amherst Masquers, and "Sauce for the Gander," a musical revue, will be produced by three undergraduates.

Two 7-year-old girls were among the fifteen junior high and elementary school children who received gold medals for their skill in poster designing yesterday by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

THE Chaco war with Bolivia dominates every aspect of life in Paraguay today. Entering the country by train, one has no difficulty in realizing that it is a nation at war. The first large town is Encarnacion. In its station is this sign:

BERLIN. THE first of the new books of which I want to tell you is Grete von Urbanitzki's original and clever novel, "Karin und die Welt der Manner" (Zsolnay, Vienna). Here we have a young woman who boldly wants to invade that masculine world which is perhaps the most inaccessible for women -- the world of politics and finance, of stocks and bonds and international pacts and trade relations.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 14. -- A new era in the production of moving pictures, with classics of American and European literature displayed as film dramas, was forecast this afternoon by William Lewin of Newark, chairman of the committee on photoplay appreciation of the National Council of English Teachers.

TUCSON, Ariz., April 14. -- The finest examples of prehistoric cotton fabrics ever found in the Southwest, all at least 1,000 years old, have just been given to the Arizona State Museum by the Hohokam Society of Tucson.

During the month of March 166 l%Ianhattan properties with an aggregate assessed valuation of $17,842,000 were sold in foreclosure actions, an increase over the total for the previous month, when 116 foreclosures involving property assessed at $10,933,000 were recorded, according to figures on realty activity compiled by the Record and Guide.
ST. LOUIS, April 14 (AP). -- Rogers Hornsby's Browns today made it two straight over the Cardinals and evened up the city championship series with a 4-to-2 victory.

Moscow, March 29. A MIDDLE-AGED, unobtrusively dressed woman took a long look at the mass of people who were trying to board a street ear headed for Theatre Square and then decided to make her way in at the front platform.

THIS is a competently written story about a strangely sensitive and inhibited nature. Katherine had a repressed girlhood, living with her sloppily artistic mother. At 17 she married Paul, a successful young architect. His passionate love frightened and chilled her.

Mme. Maria May Savage, who likes to call herself "the oldest chorus girl in the world," finished her twenty-sixth season at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday and prepared to start her usual Spring and Summer work of teaching singing and dramatics in her studio at 310 West Seventy-second Street.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Disclosure that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh had been questioned secretly by Department of Justice officials concerning the private air mail systems of the country brought a demand today from Republican members of the special air mail investigating committee of the Senate that the incident be investigated.

Hitlerism disturbs the peace of the United States even now by sending its agents of propaganda and destruction to apologize for its enormities and spread its poison here. Revelations from regions as far apart as Massachusetts and California disclose its underground activities.

The Department of Health will start an intensive ten-week diphtheria immunization drive in Manhattan and Brooklyn beginning tomorrow, Commissioner John L. Rice announced yesterday. The slogan of the campaign will be "Every Child Under Six Years of Age Immunized Before July."
Nineteen members of the Cambridge University Rugby squad sailed for England last night on the Carinthia of the Cunard Line. Two of the party decided to wait over and return on the Mauretania.

A message from President Roosevelt in recognition of the Pan-American Society's efforts to promote better understanding among the people of the Western Hemisphere was read by John L. Merrill, president of the organization, in a radio broadcast over station WOR yesterday in connection with its Pan-American Day observance.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP). -- Clark Griffith, baseball's old fox, is counting on President Roosevelt to bring his Washington club the same good luck this year that he did in the 1933 race for the American League pennant.
Here is a book to which any traveler through the Western desert should give a place in his luggage.
EL PASO, Texas, April 14 (AP). -- Norma Talmadge, former motion picture star, has obtained a Mexican divorce from her husband, Joseph M. Schenck, motion picture producer.

HAVANA, April 14. -- A policeman and a girl student were wounded and many heads were cracked late this afternoon when high school students held a demonstration in the Central Park district against government aggressiveness and arrests of students by the military authorities in the interior.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The Gridiron Club, entering its fiftieth year, gave its annual Spring dinner tonight, satirizing the first year of the New Deal. For President Roosevelt, the guest of honor, and its more than 400 other guests, leaders in all branches of American life, the club depicted in song and skit the administration's policies and some of the major political happenings since March, 1933.

KANSAS for the first time in her history is at a loss what to do on the Liquor question. Thus far the chief effect of national repeal has been bewilderment. From the wreck of prohibition the State has salvaged little but her old hatred of the saloon.
GALESBURG, Ill., April 14. -- Knox College recently checked the post-college records of some of its "most able students," its Phi Betta Kappas, and found significant results.
After reaching the lowest figures of the week, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday under week-end covering and ended with gains of 2 to 4 points.
PARIS, April 14. -- Two important suggestions for reforming the French Constitution have been approved by the Parliamentary subcommission appointed for this purpose.

CHANGCHUN, April 13. -- "Four pilots instead of two were in the Soviet Army plane that landed in Manchukuo a month ago. Two were deserters from the Soviet Army and the others, hitherto unnamed, were the twin spectres, fear and discontent."

THE religious struggle in Germany is now being carried on along two fronts. To the conflict between old-line Protestants and Nazi religious zealots has now been added a contest between the latter and the Catholics.

A NOVEL dealing with history in the making needs, like an omelette, to be served up piping hot. The dates appended to this story of Northern India during 1931 show that it has been in process of writing between November, 1931, and February, 1934.
BERLIN, April 14. -- The Nazi concentration camps in Prussia still shelter about 2,800 so-called political prisoners; another half hundred remain confined in jails in Berlin and elsewhere.

Scrubbed, rubbed and burnished until all seems to be aglitter, in the proverbial pink of condition, the sixteen clubs of the two major leagues will launch the 1934 championship campaign this week with every indication at hand that baseball will play a vital part in making folks forget the recent drab years of universal depression and general lamentation.

An advance of 0.2 point in The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to 108.9 on Tuesday from 108.7 the week previous reflected a mixed movement of individual commodities.

BERLIN, April 14 (AP). -- In an attempt to stem a rising tide of opposition to his dictatorial Nazi church regime, Reich Bishop Ludwig Mueller today proclaimed amnesty for hundreds of pastors expelled from their posts because they challenged his authority and views.

MOOSONEE, Canada's newest railway terminus, on James Bay, is an anomally in that it has neither talkies nor automobiles, in the plural. The seventeen children of school age, who help to make up Moosonee's population numbering around 500, have never known the joy of shrieking over Mickey Mouse, and their acquaintance with motor vehicles is confined to the sight of a truck owned by a Mr. Beamer.

IN this book Dr. Plath gives the result of thirteen years of study of the bumblebees of North America, especially those of the New England States. His investigations have added much to the information available on the differences between species and helped to solve several problems, including those connected with the behavior of the "cuckoo" or parasitic bumblebees and the mystery of "trumpeter" bees.

HERE is one of those historical romances of the kind that were so alarmingly prevalent before the war. Granting the genre, one agrees with Mr. Adams, who has written an engaging preface arguing the point that minor inaccuracies in details are unimportant so long as the spirit of the people and the times is faithfully interpreted, so long as the larger truths are recognized and the historical characters honestly portrayed.

We are proceeding in the only way possible under our Constitution to bring about the coordination of industrial operations that every great nation has found necessary, and which has been brought about only through political revolution in so many other countries in recent years. We have not been engaged in planning a political revolution, but having accepted the fact of an economic revolution we have planned to avoid any danger of a political revolution.

MADRID, April 14 (AP). -- Scattered riots and strikes marred the celebration today of the third anniversary of the founding of the Spanish Republic. Seventy Fascists were arrested and the Fascist headquarters was closed at Seville after a clash between Nationalists and Fascists.

THE East and the West are meeting and the connecting link is no longer the stately camel caravan, the rushing automobile, or even the airways, but a line of steel stretching for 1,200 miles across the desert which will bring the mineral resources of Iraq, ancient land of the Caliphs, to Mediterranean shores.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 14. -- Twenty-five unidentified Biblical-Talmudic narratives, lost since the tenth century, have been brought to light and published by the Yale University Press in a unique Arabic codex in ancient manuscript form, edited by Dr. Julian J. Obermann, visiting professor of Semitic languages at Yale University.

Several delegations of employed and unemployed CWA workers were received by Wililam Hodson, commissioner of the Department of Public Welfare, in his offices at 50 Lafayette Street yesterday morning. He heard and answered complaints of discrimination against racial groups, manual workers and while-collar workers.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 14. -- City College of New York defeated Rutgers in the opening baseball game of the season here today, 5 to 2. In spite of adverse weather conditions, the visitors played well in the field, being charged with only two errors.

PALE BEACH. -- Definite evidence of the prolonging of the Palm Beach season, a matter of two months a decade ago and of five months this year, is seen in the colonists who are buying homes for permanent Winter residence, or leasing apartments or villas for next season, before their departure.

THIS is another lively tale of Mournful Martin, the tall, sad-faced, philosophic old cow puncher, of young Frank Fleager, whom Mournful rescued from the bad ways of the boy's father, a notorious fugitive gunman, and of the old ranchers Danforth and Longley, characters concerning whose exploits Charles Wesley Sanders has written several other tall yarns that have won considerable popularity.

AMONG a multitude of indifferent biographers who exploit personalities, at once familiar and romantic, Mr. Sencourt stands out excellently. With eager industry, he has ransacked the archives of Europe, haunting the mansions where the memories of the late Bonapartes, like faded hangings, adorn salons, once radiant, and arguing particular points with a host of historians, all of them adequate in their eminence for discourse thus Olympian.

The hopeless struggle to save the life of Abraham Lincoln from the time he was shot until his death, sixty-nine years ago today, is tersely described in the diary of Dr. Charles S. Taft, now part of the collection of Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The last of the five traditional North and South sports fixtures will be held this week when the sixteenth annual target tournament is conducted at the Gun Club. Three North and South events, the sixteen-yard championship, the handicap and the doubles, will occupy Wednesday and Thursday, while the North Carolina State championship tournament is listed for Friday and Saturday.

LONDON, April 9 (By Mail). -- A football bladder strapped to his chest has kept an almost completely paralyzed patient, S. Crosby Halahan, breathing continuously for the past six months, it appears from a report by Dr. Phyllis Tookey Kerridge of the London School of Hygiene to the current issue of The Lancet, medical journal published here.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 14 (AP). -- It was learned on good authority today that the University of Michigan probably will send its football team to New York to meet Columbia in 1935.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Relations between the United States and the twenty other republics of the Western Hemisphere have at no time in our history been "on a more firm and sound foundation." Secretary Hull told an audience celebrating Pan American Day here tonight.

GENEVA, April 14. -- The only European countries that kept out of the World War took the lead today in volunteering to share the risk, at which the United States and Great Britain still shy, of trying to prevent another world war by accepting in advance stronger guarantees to enforce disarmament and peace.

One of the largest entertainments of the Spring season took place last night in the grand ballroom of the Pierre where a ball was given to raise funds for Briarcliff Holiday House in Briarcliffe Manor, N.Y. Several hundred members of society thronged the ballroom for the event, the net proceeds from which will aid the institution in providing shelter and care for orphans and week-end holidays for young business women.

OVER and under the rivers of New York the engineers are busy again in bold adventures and spectacular enterprises. A major depression cannot discourage bridge builders and tunnel diggers for long. On the east side and the west side of town they have resumed their large task of correcting Manhattan's insularity, of binding together the far-spread parts of the greater city and integrating the municipal miscellany that composes the metropolitan district.

WHY American built planes which are eligible for the annual Bendix transcontinental high-speed contest are to be barred from the MacRobertson England-to-Australia air races is to be asked English race officials by the National Aeronautic Association.

ENGLAND this year is celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, which was fashioned after the New York organization of the same name. The founding of the English society was the beginning of an expanding program for the protection of children by law.

ON hundreds of slowly greening hillsides in America today the little red schoolhouse, hopelessly locked for months, has opened its creaking doors. Carpenters, whistling over new-made jobs, reshingle its leaking roof, while over in the next township PWA workmen pour in the concrete foundations of a prouder scholastic structure suited to the modern age.
An effort to descend further into the sea than any man has yet succeeded in doing will be made this Summer by Dr. William Beebe, who announced yesterday his new plans for deep-sea exploration.

BEHIND Miss Gibbons's pleasant spoofing lies the same attitude that disperses street riots with a fire hose. She is conservative to the marrow. She doesn't like to be bothered with disturbing visions of Utopia, and she has no patience with characters in books or people in life who try to dream themselves into a state of felicity not properly theirs.

In newspaper comment, in letters to the press, most of all in private conversation, it is darkly hinted that if all the facts were known we should think differently about the whole thing.

NOW that things have slackened up a bit, George C. Tyler has been sitting down with J. C. Furnas to scribble off his reminiscences. Very good reminiscences they are, too, published by Bobbs, Merrill under the genial caption of "Whatever Goes Up --," and further denominated on the dust jacket as "The Hazardous Fortunes of a Natural Born Gambler."

GARDENERS who like the new zinnias, in modern flower forms and delicate pastel shades of color, often wish that they might have them earlier in the season. Those who have tried transplanting zinnias instead of sowing them in the open where they are to grow know that it is a simple matter to gain three weeks or more.

BOSTON, April 14 (AP). -- Motion-picture producers were taken to task today by Mrs. August Belmont of New York and A. Lawrence Lowell, president emeritus of Harvard University. Speaking at a luncheon meeting they accused a majority of producers of issuing films detrimental to the character and morale of the youth of the nation.

THE lives of even the greatest executive musicians are, even more truly than Keats's name, writ in water. The age that has heard them passes, and with it all distinct and definite memory and knowledge of their work.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP). -- "A drastic reduction" in hours in the anthracite industry was recommended in a final report today by the investigating committee named by Miss Perkins instead of the thirty-two hours a week urged in the first report.

NORFOLK, Va., April 11. -- The North Carolina Republican convention, which recently handed over the leadership of the party to a new 36-year-old chairman, also declared its enmity to the State's 9-month-old sales tax and thereby fixed the chief issue between the parties in North Carolina this year.

MOSLEMS who have been rebelling in Chinese Turkestan for nearly a year recently took Kashgar and then fell out among themselves over sharing the contents of the Chinese Governor's treasure chest. Now the Tungans, or Chinese Moslems, have been overcome by their Turki allies at Kashgar and a republic of Islamstan has been declared.

What the demand for locomotives will be in the near future is described as hinging on a situation in which are several conflicting factors. When the railroads were expanding their systems, the yearly demand for locomotives was steady, one problem of operating forces then being to find equipment to move the freight.

NEWARK, N.J., April 14. -- After hearing the story of a dramatically staged "murder" and the alleged extortion of $1,500 from one of the witnesses, who gladly paid rather than he implicated in the "crime," the police today arrested five men and charged all with conspiracy.

BUENOS AIRES, April 13. -- Dark, heavy storm clouds are gathering again on the South American horizon. The Leticia dispute between Colombia and Peru threatens soon to give this continent its second war. The Chaco war between Bolivia and Paraguay is entering its third Winter with no indications of peace in the near future.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court dismissed on Friday disciplinary proceedings filed against Robert Morgan McGauley. The decision was based on a report by Lloyd Paul Stryker, to whom the case was referred. The opinion, written by Presiding Justice Edward R. Finch, said:

Many seats have been purchased for the recital by Gladys Swarthout, mezzo-soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, and Frank Chapman, baritone, which will take place on Wednesday night at the clubhouse of the Junior League of New York for the benefit of the Hartley House Music School.

A system of regular shipping service between the Russian ports on the Black Sea and the United States will be established by the Soviet Government, as a result of the successful visit to New York of the motorship Kim, it was announced yesterday.

GENEVA, April 13. -- The closing of licensed brothels in seven British port areas has been followed by generally good results, according to the report submitted today by the British Social Hygiene Council to the League of Nations Committee on Traffic in Women.

The disappearance of Ian Campbell, a brilliant young research chemist, causes his employer. Sir Samuel Blakely, to send for Chief Inspector Macdonald of Scotland Yard and ask him to help find the young man. Campbell has been working on the problem of extracting oil directly from coal and is believed to have brought his experiments to a successful conclusion.

ALTHOUGH Mr. Uzzell delivers some shrewd opinions in this interpretative, and very catholic, anthology, one feels that his methods would scarcely appeal to such purists as the editors of Story or Edward J. O'Brien. Mr. Uzzell has an open mind.

THE Prince of Wales is now interested in a new hobby, gardening, and has just become a member of the Rhododendron Society. Practically all of his spare time is being spent in his garden at Fort Belvedere, near Sunningdale, where the Prince seems to enjoy doing a certain amount of weeding and planting.

Unemployed and destitute British veterans of the World War living in this country will be the chief beneficiaries of the gala benefit performance to be held tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House under the auspices of the Associated British Charities.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The United States probably will request an increase in its export quota under the world wheat agreement before approving a system of minimum export prices agreed upon today by the World Wheat Advisory Commission, it was indicated by agricultural officials.

PARIS, April 14. -- Pertinax, in an editorial in L'Echo De Paris, lists a number of demands the French should make in his opinion in their answer to the British question regarding what guarantees they would consider adequate to sign an arms convention.

So weak from his attempt at suicide that he fainted twice during the proceedings, Max R. Schneller, self-styled physician, who obtained an appointment as resident physician at Hart's Island Reformatory, pleaded guilty yesterday in West Farms Court to a charge of practicing medicine without a license.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- President Roosevelt discussed the legislative program for the remainder of the Congressional session with Senate leaders, signed the Norris-Rankin resolution for an investigation of power rates and attended the Gridiron Club's Spring dinner.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 14. -- Yale's baseball team, connecting for five runs in the eighth inning, triumphed over the Dartmouth nine, 9 to 3, in the opening game of the Eastern Intercollegiate League season today. Rain fell twice during the contest but failed to bring a halt to the proceedings.
The Cambridge University rugby team left these shores last night with concrete evidence that it had succeeded in its mission of helping to elevate the standard of play in this country.

New York and Brooklyn department store advertising showed a heavy gain for the eighth consecutive month, in March, the total of 3,149,586 representing an increase of almost 18 per cent over the 2,669,454 lines for the corresponding month last year, according to Media Records.

Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday that New York University had established a new unit, tentatively called Division of General Education, to administer all adult education and other extension activities, effective July 1.

Members of the New York department of the Reserve Officers Association of the United States will hold their annual convention here on May 4 and 5, Lieut. Col. W.A. Hardenbergh, president of the association, announced yesterday.

THE first part of this new novel by Sidney Fairway contains so much that is interesting and worth while, the question it propounds is one of so much importance, it seems a very great pity that it should slump so badly toward the close.

The British Minister of Health, Sir Hilto Young, had appointed a committee of experts to obtain the best designs for apartment houses and the modernizing of old buildings in London, the designs were made and the committee reported and all was set for a new london, when I-I. Berry, chairman of the building acts committee of the London County Council, 'discovered a bundle of old laws which seriously obstructed the execution of the new plans.

BARCELONA, April 2. -- The position of the press in this region is still rather precarious, notwithstanding the substitution of a republic and democracy for the dictatorship with its regime of confiscations, suspensions and finings of newspapers.
PALM BEACH, Fla., April 14. -Many gatherings marked the concluding dinner tonight at the Beach Club.

THE new simplicities, the more general rather than specifically racial style that Ernest Bloch has adopted in his last score, the "Avodah Hakodesh," given its first American performance by the Schola Cantorum last Wednesday night, may puzzle the curious listener, fascinated in the past by the richness, exoticism and stress of Bloch's eminently racial music.
PHILADELPHIA, April 14. -Pennsylvania lost to the Penn A.C. in the thirteenth inning on Franklin Field today, 7 to 6, when Catcher Al Harwi, formerly of Lehigh, drove home Pitcher Tither.

Because of the observance yesterday of Pan-American Day there is special reason to recall the address delivered by President ROOSEVELT on the same occasion last year. It was then that he pledged his Administration to what he described as "the policy of the good neighbor."

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 14. -- Public education in normal times as well as in times of depression is a responsibility of the college-trained woman. This conclusion will be taken back to Vassar College alumnae groups having a membership of about 8,000 by delegates to a three-day conference here.

I am well aware we have so far kept aloof from the great shirt movements of other lands where they have Red Shirts, Black Shirts, Brown Shirts, also blue, green and yellow ones. And so when I seen some piece in the paper as how some one had suggested we organize a Clean Shirt affair I says to my wife I guess I'll advocate such an outfit.

NOW that "Tarzan" is completed, MGM is faced with a new problem, that of the seeming brutality to animals. It is one of the elements on the screen for which American audiences will not stand. The slaughter of a number of lions is pictured which, under ordinary circumstances, would arouse a storm of protest from the 2,700 S.P.C.A. organizations in this country.

WHEN the transcontinental record for transport planes was broken last February with a flight by the Douglas DC-1 with ten passengers and the final load of mail hauled under its old contract by Transcontinental and Western Air, weather conditions for the trip were forecast with phenomenal accuracy by the so-called "polar front" or air-mass-analysis method.

ROME, April 14. -- If anything was required to make clear the gravity of the conflict that has arisen between the Holy See and the present regime in Germany, that purpose could not have been better achieved than by the personal intervention of Pope Pius twice in rapid succession in the controversy raging between Berlin and Vatican City.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- I think, as the Senate Banking and Currency Committee has agreed, that an independent commission selected by the President, subject to confirmation by the Senate, could more effectively administer the Stock Exchange Act than some other board already charged with complex and responsible functions.

THE identity of the murderer in this story does not long remain a secret. The police know, and so does Albert Campion, the brilliant amateur who has appeared in other stories by Margery Allingham. The difficulty is to prove anything, for the murders have been so ingeniously planned and executed that there is not a shred of evidence that would have the slightest weight in court.
CHICAGO, April 12. -- Applied science has reached a coldly efficient hand into one of the famous landmarks of the Chicago region and snatched from it the human element of romance.

Teams representing Public School 73 of the Bronx and Public School 82 of Manhattan tallied twelve points each to share the honors in the seventh and eighth year division of the annual city P.S.A.L. elementary schools championship swimming meet in the City College pool yesterday.
BABYLON, L.I., April 14. The annual field trials of the Babylon Hunt Club began today on the estate of Colonel M. Robert Guggenheim at North Babylon, where the puppy and derby classes were judged.

Fortunately for novelists, love is blind but fate is helpful. Jo was too young to recognize love when, at 16, she married. Her husband was a solid citizen twenty years older than his bride. The first year the twins came, and Jo was devoted to them.

WE have often wondered why that remarkable family of Sforza condottieri, viragoes, dukes and patrons of art and culture who ruled in one city or another of Renaissance Italy longer than any other dynasty (except the present House of Savoy), should have been so long neglected when less interesting and less important figures have been so lavishly welcomed in English.

AN ancient, recurring theme is that of the man absorbed by some special interest who must forever combat the hostility of a possessive wife. James Elroy Flecker, to whom Miss Mannin owes her title, once phrased the problem succinctly. "* * * It was ever thus.

ARLINGTON, Texas, April 14. -- W.C. Stroube's Clarify returned to form today at Arlington Downs to score a surprise victory in the mile and a sixteenth of the $2,500 added Governor's Handicap, the feature race.

IT is all up to you, says Dr. Williams. You can limit your expectation of life to the generous allotment of the psalmist, three-score years and ten, with the likelihood that it will be considerably less, or you can decide early in the game that you would like to add to that another decade or two.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- An investigation of reduced railroad fares in the South and West was ordered today by the Interstate Commerce Commission following protests from the National Recovery Administration against continuation of existing rates after May 31.

BERLIN, April 14. -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, President of the Reichsbank, today issued official invitations to representatives of Germany's long-term and medium-term creditors to meet in the Reichsbank Building in Berlin at 3 P.M. on April 27 for the new debt conference agreed upon last January.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Early agreement on a plan for extending Federal credit directly to industry so that recovery may be accelerated further by private business activity was forecast today after a conference between President Roosevelt and Senator Glass.

THE price war between wholesale and retail dealers in fish, which has tied up food worth hundreds of thousands of dollars, has fixed public attention on an industry that plays a large part in supplying the tables of the city.

With all of the enthusiasm which has marked the participation of Western crews in the East, Marietta College of Marietta, Ohio, is looking forward to the visit of that crew to Poughkeepsie this year. The Poughkeepsie trip has been made the objective of the season.
With the beginning of racing at Jamaica on Saturday there will be launched what many consider the most important New York racing season since the formation of the Jockey Club in 1894.

LONDON, April 14 (Canadian Press). -- England defeated Scotland, 3 -- 0, in their international soccer classic today before 92,000 persons in Wembley Stadium. Bastin of the Arsenal scored in the first half and Brook of Manchester City and Bowers of Derby County tallied near the close of the match.

PIERCE-ARROW announced yesterday the introduction of a new line of lower-priced eights to supplement its series of eights and twelves first presented in January. The new cars have a base list price of $2,195.

DEMOCRACY rampant is the theme of a week that has, stimulatingly and harassingly, witnessed the debut of two no-jury mass attacks. The Society of Independent Artists, established at Grand Central Palace, got under way on Friday -- too late for notice here -- and was reported in yesterday's art column.

Department stores, chains and independent merchants shaped plans during the week to govern themselves by the wage allowance of 10 per cent to be added under the General Retail Code to net invoice cost of merchandise, which goes into effect next Thursday.

FORTUNE'S favorite is a term that might well be applied to Delia Seaton as we meet her in the opening chapters of this novel. She is the daughter of a rich and indulgent father and the wife of a man who adores her and who is the idol of the British public, for he is a famous international cricketer.

Excepting rubber and sugar, which were affected by special conditions, the principal commodity futures were marked here yesterday by hesitation or weakness. Trading was moderate and price changes in general were small. There was no trading in raw silk futures, that market being closed on Saturdays.
The West Point Cadet Choir of 167 voices will be heard in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, at 11 A.M. today. Many of the cadets will be guests tonight at the Hotel Lincoln.

The Merchants Association of New York has placed a memorandum in the hands of Duncan U. Fletcher, chairman of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, and Sam Rayburn, chairman of the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce, suggesting the immediate amendment of the Federal Securities Act in twenty-one particulars.

MADRID, April 14. -- Most of the Socialist program, born in the heydey of the Left Wing's power, has been rudely dissipated as the second Spanish republic celebrates its third anniversary. The Socialists protest vehemently that the "reactionary Right Wing intends to repeal all of our reform legislation."
GENEVA, April 14. -- Two of the most acute international problems in relation to Germany were handled in Basle and Geneva this week.

ALTHOUGH this book has been printed for use as a text at the Command and General Staff School and is intended for a limited circle of readers, it should be placed in the category of works that no student of the World War may disregard.
Seven entries already have been made for the Bermuda race, which xwill be started off Sarah's Ledge, New London, Conn., on Sunday, June 24.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- The first move in the new NRA drive for swift and sure punishment of violators of its codes was revealed today with an announcement that a show cause order had been issued by a Kansas City Federal Court against five alleged violators of the cleaning and dyeing code.

CLEVELAND, April 14 (AP). -From the progressive Republican Senator, Gerald P. Nye, came today the prediction that President Roosevelt will soon shake up the NRA to "divorce its leadership from big business."
Pursuit of a small dog that bit four persons halted traffic for a half hour on St. Nicholas Avenue near 158th Street yesterday morning and caused excitement in the neighborhood.

THE Disarmament Conference's bureau or steering committee met at Geneva last week and decided to summon the full conference on May 23, in order to try to reach some armament agreement -- which Anthony Eden of the British Foreign Office says must be reached soon, if at all.

THREE years ago yesterday the Second Spanish Republic was created at the polls. Twenty-four million people who were supposed to be voting on municipal officers chose by this method to say to Alfonso XIII: "We are done with Kings.

The Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania brought its forty-sixth annual production to New York yesterday and deposited it, for afternoon and evening performances on the stage of Mecca Temple. The title of this year's product is "Easy Pickins" and, in the lengthy roster of Mask and Wig shows, it must rank well toward the top.

FEUCHTWANGER says that this book "reaches an impressive height which is absolutely original." Eric Knight achieves this peak in his vigorous and sympathetic manner of portraying a sensitive individual born just before the advent of this tumultuous century.

The New York Infirmary for Women and Children is to receive the net proceeds of two entertainments arranged for the near future. The first of these is the third in a series of "gala Tuesday evenings" at the Casino de Paree, taking place this week.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 14. -- Fire in the Capitol basement early today destroyed part of Puerto Rico's basic election records and damaged others. It is believed the fire started during the all-night legislative session.

PARIS, Aprill4. -- The Doumergue government continued today to put its budgetary economies into effect despite strong opposition from the civil servants, who are preparing country-wide manifestations for tomorrow and Monday, and the tempered dissatisfaction of the war veterans at the government's refusal to postpone the pension cuts until July 1.
The suggestion of Lloyd M. Crosgrave in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES that a conservative party is needed sounds a salutary note in the present depressive politico-economic fiasco.

NORWALK, Conn., April 14 (AP). -- A drowning verdict was given tonight by Dr. William H. McMahon, Medical Examiner, in the death of Arthur Todd, aged 70, a wealthy retired business man. State Police said the case might be turned over to the State's Attorney.
CLEVELAND, April 14 (AP). -- O.P. Van Sweringen, Joseph R. Nutt and W.M. Baldwin requested a speedy trial today of charges that they falsified records and reports of the closed Union Trust Company.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 14. -- The undefeated Navy and Princeton tens battled to a 2 -- 2 tie on Goldie Field this afternoon in the first lacrosse game between the two teams for seven years. A ten-minute extra period failed to break the deadlock.

GEORGE RAFT'S leading woman in "The Trumpet Blows," at the Paramount, is Frances Drake, who made her American film debut not long ago with Mr. Haft in "Bolero." Although she was born in New York, Miss Drake was carried off, when she was 4, to Canada, where her father, a stock broker, has mining interests.

Younger members of society will act as manikins in various departments of Arnold, Constable Co. tomorrow and Tuesday, when a percentage of all sales there will be donated to the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. They are the Misses Helen Anna Shepard.

Camp Tera, in Bear Mountain Park, established for unemployed women at the suggestion of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt by the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration and maintained through the Winter with a limited capacity, will be enlarged to care for 200 women this Summer.

The New York Athletic Club, holder of the National A.A.U. indoor championship, added to its honors by capturing the senior metropolitan A.A.U. 400-yard relay title at the swimming meet held in the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A. pool last night.

DUBLIN, April 13. -- The tragic sudden death of William Wallace McDowell, the United States Minister, while speaking at a dinner of welcome in his honor at Dublin Castle last Monday has overshadowed everything political in the Irish Free State this week.

The ninth annual military ball of the New York University chapter of Scabbard and Blade will take place Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event is under the patronage of Chancellor and Mrs. Harry Woodburn Chase, the deans of the University Heights colleges of N.Y.U., high-ranking officers of the army and Reserve Corps and their wives.

The Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity is ready to turn over the Mount Prospect Reservoir, which covers eight acres in Brooklyn, as a site for the Brooklyn College, Commissioner Maurice P. Davidson announced last night in a radio address over Station WOR.

Consolidated gross sales of the International Paper Company and subsidiaries in 1933 amounted to $79,758,774, an increase of $6,261,711 from 1932. The net loss after all charges, including depreciation and depletion, was $4,430,528. In addition, $1,865,080 was transferred to reserves to apply against an investment in the Newsprint Bond and Share Company, making a total reduction in surplus of $6,295,608.

A Washington geologist plays the part of detective in this story of wholesale slaughter in a cave in the mountains of Virginia. The cave has been discovered -- or rediscovered -- only a short time before the story opens, and Bayard Ash, the geologist, has been invited by Andrew Carter, the owner, to be present at its formal opening to the public.

WINTER HOLIDAY," the fourth book dealing with the children who have already figured in "Swallows and Amazons," "Swallowdale" and "Peter Duck," seems to indicate that Mr. Ransome will be able to go on indefinitely keeping us informed of the doings of this enterprising group of young people.

RENEWAL of the non-aggression pacts between the Soviet Union and the Baltic States of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania marks a continuance of Russia's policy of negotiating anti-war agreements with her neighbors. As far back as 1926 the Communist State began to sound her neighbors regarding such treaties, and in the last two years succeeded in completing arrangements with a number of countries.

WASHINGTON, April 54 (AP). -- Redrafting of the Fletcher-Rayburn stock market regulations bill neared completion today when the House Interstate Commerce Subcommittee decided on sections pertaining to segregation of brokers and dealers and adopted a provision for the regulation of over-the-counter trading.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 14. -- As new plans were being announced for the investigation of Senator Thayer, Governor Lehman signed today the first bill passed by the Legislature in his program of measures for stricter regulation of the public utilities.

LODON, March 29. "DOUBLE DOOR," by Elizabeth McFadden [it was shown in New York this Fall -- Ed.], is what lawyers call a test case. With little concealment, it is old-fashioned melodrama of the kind that was extremely popular in servants' halls during Victorian days.

EXETER, N.H., April 14. -- Exeter won its opening baseball game of the season from Huntington School of Boston today, 8 to 5. All three of Exeter's pitchers were wild because of the wet weather and slippery ball, giving a total of twelve passes.

CHICAGO, April 12. -- Political discussion in Illinois, provoked by Tuesday's primary election, centres around three major developments of interest. Down-State the complete victory of Speaker Rainey in his fight for renomination has made a distinct impression upon those who thought dissatisfaction with the New Deal policies might result in his defeat, or in giving him at least a terrifyingly tight squeeze.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 14. -- Paul Mellon's fine steeplechaser Drinmore Lad, with the veteran Jim Ryan up, today won the fourteenth running of the Middleburg Cup, turning the stiff four miles in the good time of 7:33 3-5.

The Italian liner Conte di Savoia was withdrawn from the transatlantic service last week to enter dry-dock at Genoa. It was the first time she had left her regular run since her maiden voyage in November, 1932. She will be repainted and overhauled.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- A sharp rise in automobile production featured the domestic busi ness situation last week, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly report. Assemblies were estimated at approximately 90,000 units, nearly two and a half times as large as a year ago, and this was reflected in a further rise in employment in the industry.
LONDON, April 14. -- This is the week-end in which the British birthrate for thoughts from wishes always breaks the record for the year.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was active and strong yesterday. Calling by the Treasury of two additional series of Fourth Liberty 4 1/4s, the Series B and H, in the amount of $1,200,000,000 for redemption on Oct. 15, sent opening transactions in them to 102 13-32, whereas the uncalled bonds of the issue began at 104 4-32, up 4-32 point from the previous close.

The sophomore class at Barnard College defeated the freshmen by a 55.5 to 44.5 score in the thirty-first annual Greek festival of the Pythian Games, held yesterday in the college gymnasium, Broadway and 117th Street.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, April 12. -- The flow of "hot oil" in East Texas has practically ceased as the result of the shutting down of thirty-four small oil refineries, said to have been the chief market for bootleg petroleum in that section, and, unless the courts invalidate the new Refinery Law, the outlook is that production in the field henceforth will be rigidly controlled.

PITTSBURGH, April 14 (AP). -The tattered maps of the Spanish Main -- you remember, "Go East 75 paces from a tree stump, ," -have their counterpart in the 1934 bandits' code. The modern system, however, is used by the robber in escaping with the gold.

For the lover of pools or water gardens, here is an invaluable little book. It is so small that the commuter can carry it in his pocket and yet so profusely illustrated that almost nothing is left to the reader's imagination.

THE author, who has been well and favorably known for his legal acumen since his elevation from a judgeship in Baltimore to his present high office (1924) previously distinguished himself (1928) by his history of the Court of Appeals at the time of its sesquicentennial anniversary; it was not certain, as he then pointed out, that it was not more than 150 years old.

The report of the President's Committee on Wild-Life Restoration has a frontispiece by "Ding." It is an appealing cartoon, showing bear and moose, deer and duck, partridge and rabbit, and even a little song bird up on a twig, calling for help from a public which has too long left them to fend for themselves against the advancing hosts of civilization.

THE new marvels of the "movie-tone" method of recording sound through radio amplification tubes have now been introduced into bird study. It has been the pioneer task of Mr. Brand of the Museum of Natural History, working in conjunction with the Cornell School of Ornithology, to record the songs of wild birds first through the microphone and then, with interesting intermediary steps, upon phonograph disks.

Rehearsals for the elaborate pageantry to feature the second Opera Ball on April 27 at the Metropolitan Opera House are now being held under the direction of Ben Ali Haggin, producer of the pageant, which is to be called "Le Roi S'Amuse Fontainebleau."

Sharp rises in deposits and in the number of depositors, reflecting apparently increases in employment, salaries and wages, have been reported by the mutual savings banks of New York State for the first quarter of this year. Deposits in these banks amounted on March 31 to $5,110,649,204, a gain of $24,371,704 for the three months, the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 14. -- Reorganization and industrial projects are included in securities issues proposed to be issued in a group of nine registration statements filed under the Securities Act with the Federal Trade Commission and made public today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 14. -- City College of New York lost to a fast and aggressive Rutgers lacrosse team today, 14 -- 8. The Scarlet ten, led by Dan Van Mater, who was playing his first intercollegiate game, piled up a 7-1 lead in the first half.

THE Private Life of Don Juan" is the title of the motion picture which Douglas Fairbanks is at present making for London Films. A cable to the United Artists office here, which will release the film, says it will be another Fairbanks swashbuckler, and that he will have seven leading women in it.

The article in THE TIMES headed "Plan to Mobilize 25,000,000 Thrifty" was very interesting reading to me, as it was somewhat in line with plans which I have outlined to prominent corporation and association executives during the last few months.

MAYOR LAGUARDIA has proclaimed his desire to see Governors Island -- which is to New York, roughly, what the Tower is to London -- become the city's airport "within five minutes of the Battery." Frank Oliver, one of the city's representatives in Congress, has got included in the Army Appropriation Bill, recently passed by the House, $25,000 for a survey preliminary to the realization of the project.

In a discourse delivered a few weeks ago before the Royal Institution Lord RUTHERFORD extended "congratulations to our American colleagues for "the masterly way they opened up and "developed so rapidly" a knowledge of a new form of hydrogen "which it is "certain will prove of great scientific "and practical importance in the fu"ture."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 12. -- Although Washington and points north may incline to look upon the growing controversy over Southern wage differentials as something which involves only the right of labor to a living wage and to a greater share of the income from production, many Southerners are viewing the matter with feelings comparable to those they inherited from the war between the States.

WHEN Germany threw a much enlarged hat into the ring of the nations and announced that her people are superior to all others because they are Nordics she struck a fuse that has set off a bombardment of books that by facts, arguments, ridicule, every possible literary means has endeavored to convince her of her error and to show all the rest of the world how immature, mistaken and futile is her assumption.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., April 14. -- Students of Bryn Mawr College presented Bernard Shaw's "Pygmalion" in Goodhart Hall Friday evening and tonight and the thirteenth century miracle play, "Le Miracle de Theophile" in the library cloisters this afternoon.

THERE was speech-making in the Boston Opera House at the end of the Metropolitan Opera Company's first engagement Down East in more than two decades. "Honest opera returned to Boston last evening," A.H. Meyer had written after the opening night.
PHILADELPHIA, April 14. -- The German-Americans of this city captured the Eastern amateur soccer championship by defeating the Pfalzer Club of Brooklyn, 5 -- 1, today.
