TRENTON, N.J., April 17. -- A bill designed specifically to prevent the spreading of Nazi propaganda in New Jersey has been passed unanimously by the State Assembly.
The money market was dull and quotations for all classes of accommodation carried forward without change. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent, while the Street rate was 3/4.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Barring unforeseen developments in the world wheat situation, the United States will request an enlargement of its export quota under the international wheat agreement to 140,000,000 bushels effective Aug. 1, 1935, it was learned today in a high administrative quarter.

The number of buyers registered in town during the week ended yesterday, although showing a slight drop in comparison with the figures for the previous week, continued to be well above the number reported in the pre-Easter week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP). -- Only the signature of President Roosevelt is needed to put on the statute books the nation's first Federal compulsory production control act, the Bankhead cotton bill.

At the third of a series of testimonial dinners in honor of the fifteenth anniversary of the elevation to the Archbishopric of Patrick Cardinal Hayes, which was held last night in the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx, more than $13,000 was pledged to the Catholic Charities' drive for funds that starts next Sunday and will continue through the following week.

DALLAS, Texas, April 17. -- By permission of the New York Theatre Guild the Dallas Little Theatre presented tonight George Bernard Shaw's "Village Wooing" for the first time on any stage. Styled "a comediettina in three conversations,'' it lasted little more than an hour and was paired with Shaw's "The Man of Destiny" for the full evening's entertainment.

Attended by all the time-honored trappings of an opening day, Casey Stengel put his 1934 Dodgers on display before 28,000 at Ebbets Field yesterday and they made it a perfect day both for Casey and the fans.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET, off Lower West Coast of Mexico, April 17 (AP). -- Harassing destroyer attacks tonight against the bulk of the United States fleet, moving toward the Panama Canal, brought to a close two days of exacting secret manoeuvres involving new tactics of the navy's large submarines cooperating with destroyers.

Aside from plain frittering, there are 700 known ways of employing one's leisure time, according to the newly formed Leisure League of America, Inc. And the league, which held its organization luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria, is going to issue little pamphlets on all of them, including "Hooked Rugs," for amateur rug-hookers, and, for wives, "How to Spend Your Husband's Leisure."

PHILADELPHIA, April 17. -- A silvery, light-weight three-car train, latest addition to the Burlington Railroad's fleet, streaked over the Reading Company's tracks between Hopewell and Skillman, N.J., today at 104 miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The Wagner bill creating a National Labor Board to act as a supreme arbiter in disputes between organized labor and employers seemed to be assured a place on the legislative program of this session of Congress today as the result of a conference at the White House between President Roosevelt and Senator Wagner.

BOSTON, April 17. -- Manager Joe Cronin's first hit of the 1934 season, a slashing two-bagger to left with one out in the eleventh, started a rally that enabled his Washington Senators to conquer the rebuilt Red Sex, 6 -- 5, today before 33,336 spectators, one of the largest opening crowds in Boston's baseball history.
TOKYO, Wednesday, April 18. -- The government, in an "unofficial" statement through the semi-official Rengo News agency repeated yesterday warnings against foreign action in China.

The domestic railway equipment market is headed toward recovery and there is a prospect of a demand for locomotives for export to Russia, William C. Dickerman, president of the American Locomotive Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

Although the grain and silver markets were again unsettled, stocks had a partial recovery yesterday. Domestic corporation bonds canceled their losses of the day before, but United States Government securities were under mild pressure.

Daily average gross crude oil production of the United States last week was 2,449,300 barrels, compared with 2,337,650 barrels, an increase of 111,650 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 62,100 barrels in Oklahoma, 21,500 in California and 14,050 in Texas accounted for most of the increase.

TORONTO, April 17. -- Music followers in Toronto turned out in encouraging numbers to the opening concert of Centennial Music Week tonight and the crowds were not disappointed by the memorable reading of Beethoven's Ninth as given by the Toronto Symphony Orchestra under the leadership of Dr. Ernest MacMillan.
LONDON, April 17. -- The House of Commons today appointed Arthur Greenwood, a Laborite, to fill George Lansbury's vacant place on the Committee on Privileges.

The Weston Biscuit Company, doubling its production capacity in Passaic, N.J., has bought the Passaic Cotton Mills factory and warehouse in Brighton Avenue. The Weston plant, established in 1929 with 100 employes, last year employed 500.

Jesse L. Livermore, Wall Street operator for years, admitted at an examination in bankruptcy yesterday that two weeks after a $90,000 judgment had been obtained against him last February he assigned a $100,000 annuity to his wife, Mrs. Harriet Metz Livermore.

After an opening decline which carried the May below 11 1/2 cents a pound, prices on the Cotton Exchange developed more resistance yesterday, and a recovery of a dollar a bale left the list with a loss of 2 to a gain of 2 points on the day.

The threatened strike of ushers, doormen, ticket-takers and janitors in movie theatres loomed nearer yesterday after a meeting of theatre executives with Charles Levy, secretary of the Theatre and Amusement Employee Union, Local 118. The executives, according to a statement issued by them after the conference, "refused to negotiate further with Mr. Levy until he makes clear whom he represents."

Winners of the five scholarships offered to members of the fifth annual course in advertising, sponsored by Advertising Women of New York, Inc., were announced at a dinner given last night by the organization at the Advertising Club of New York, 23 Park Avenue.

W.W. Norton has been nominated for president of the National Association of Book Publishers, succeeding Cass Canfield of Harper Bros., who has served as president for the last two years. The election will be held at the association's annual meeting on April 25 at the Hotel St. Regis.

Federal Judge John M. Woolsey denied yesterday an application made in February by John J. Miller of Montclair, N.J., a holder of about $100,000 of guaranteed bonds, for the appointment of equity receivers for the National Surety Company and its affiliates, the Greyling Realty Corporation and the National Realty Management Company.

SHREVEPORT, La., Wednesday, April 18. -- Two companies of National Guardsmen were placed in action early today to protect the Caddo parish court house from attack by 3,000 men who rushed the building last night. The mob was attempting to seize Fred Lockhart, white, who confessed to officers the murder last Thursday of 16year-old Mae Giffin, also white.

Pasquale Amato is to sing as Pasquale Baron Scarpia in Puccini's "Tosca" at the Hippodrome on Friday of next week, it was announced last night. Besides reviving his own famous role, he also will add to the current repertory Gounod's "Romeo and Juliet" next Monday, the birthday of Shakespeare, from whom the French composer borrowed his text.

PARIS, April 17. -- Leon Trotsky's permit to reside in France has been revoked by the government. The Russian exile must leave his little house at Barbizon at once -- if he has not already gone -- and must depart from France "in the shortest possible time."
PHILADELPHIA, April 17. -- The Yankees' quest of the 1934 American League pennant with a new baseball machine got away in reverse today.

Representatives of the American Booksellers Association met with officials of the Retail Code Authority yesterday and agreed upon how Schedule B of the retail book code is to be applied. The code goes into effect tomorrow.

The annual installation exercises of Barnard College undergraduate officers for the academic year 1934-35 were held yesterday afternoon before the student body in the college gymnasium, Broadway and 117th Street. Eleven students were inducted into office and thirteen received the bear pin, the college's highest award for participation in student activities.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 17. -- A sudden strike of 2,000 gasoline filling station attendants brought dismay to motorists and overtures of peace from major oil companies here today.

Fourteen jurors from a special panel were selected in Judge Donnellan's part of General Sessions yesterday for the trial of Sava Kehaya, 43 years old, a former private banker and real estate man; his wife, Mary A. Kehaya, 31, and three others.

A portrait of the Rev. Raymond C. Knox, who yesterday completed twenty-five years of service as chaplain of Columbia University, was presented to the university in the afternoon at a ceremony in Philosophy Hall.

BARBISON, France, April 17 (AP). -- As Leon Trotsky's "fourth international" headquarters in a mysterious villa near this Paris suburb was getting ready to move, the motorcyclist whose encounter with the police had led to a raid Sunday and the sudden disclosure that M. Trotsky lived here arrived this afternoon with a batch of mail from Paris.

With more than 16,000 State income-tax returns arriving in the final mail, Wesley M. Dawson, district director of the income-tax bureau, estimated that the total number of returns received this year at the district office at 80 Centre Street was three times as great as last year.
Rentals by various garment and household furnishing concerns were among the business items reported yesterday, as follows:

Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, now a fugitive under a Federal indictment charging income tax fraud, was seen at the polls in November, 1932, in the company of "Billy Solomon" and Samuel Kantor, Democratic captain of the Seventeenth Assembly District, it was testified yesterday in Federal court.

Merchant tonnage under construction in the shipyards of the world totals 1,079,171 tons, a gain of 321,894 tons, or more than 40 per cent, in the last three months, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, which was published yesterday.

When Spring comes to the five boroughs, the chances are that the Rev. Edward Eells, "specialist in sympathetic funerals" (who is also known, paradoxically, as "the Cheer-Up Man"), will not be far behind. And sure enough, yesterday being a fine day, Brother Eells duly appeared in the office of THE NEW YORK TIMES, armed with the familiar calling card, the familiar scrapbook (full of convincing, previous write-ups) and the all-too-familiar news item.

Of Cambridge's winning all the Rugby football games while here it may well be said that there was a "general Cantabrigicity about it." But the victories of the Britishers left no sting. Rather were their American opponents grateful for the exhibition of the game as played on British fields -- a "passing" and "kicking" game.

The world's champion Giants, whose singular gyrations during their closing weeks of Spring rehearsals had given rise to sinister misgivings, yesterday gave a magnificent performance as they ushered in New York's 1934 championship baseball season at the Polo Grounds.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17. -- Returning from Venezuela after a nine-months' absence, Vincenzo Petrullo, field director for South American research at the University of Pennsylvania Museum, related today that he had been accepted as "a relative of the gods" by the hostile and primitive Yaruro tribesmen.

ROME, April 17 (AP). -- Members of the World Wheat Advisory Commission decided tonight to take up with their respective governments proposals to cut wheat acreage on a wide scale prior to their next meeting in London in May.

ALBANY, April 17. -- With opposition rising against passage of the Alger-Cook plan for relief of holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates, Governor Lehman held a series of conferences today in the hope of achieving an agreement for some kind of action before the Legislature adjourns.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., April 17 -- When a heavy coastal fog lifted just before noon today, the freighter Puszta of the Anglo-Hungarian Shipping Company, Ltd., was discovered hard aground on the north shore of Block Island.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Congress in joint session on May 20 will duplicate a ceremony first enacted 100 years ago. Tentative plans were revealed today for observing the centenary of the death of the Marquis de Lafayette.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- John Factor, wanted in England for trial on fraud charges, was arrested again today after a three-year fight against extradition. He will remain in a hotel under guard until a warrant of surrender is issued by the Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- William J. Donovan, Assistant Attorney General in the Hoover administration, will file suit tomorrow in the District of Columbia Supreme Court to enjoin Postmaster General Farley from enforcing cancellation of air mail contracts, Karl A. Crowley, Solicitor of the Postoffice Department, was informed today.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The omission from today's British budget of provision for this year's installments on Great Britain's wartime debt to the United States occasioned little surprise here. A similar procedure was followed last April, and yet the British Treasury later was able to find the comparatively modest sums needed to make two 'token" payments.

The undefeated Mount St. Michael's High School baseball team defeated New York Cathedral Prep. 5 to 2, yesterday at the Mount St. Michael's Field for its second Manhattan division C. H.S.A.A. victory and its fourth triumph of the season.

New York City has much, at stake in the closing hours of the Legislature, which is anxious to adjourn on Friday if it can. The most urgent need is for the passage of the bill extending Mayor LAGUARDIA'S economy program to the teachers and other employes of the Board of Education, failure of which would be a piece of injustice to the civil service employes generally.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP). -- The American Association opened its thirty-third season today before a total attendance which exceeded the fondest hopes of the club owners, the turnstiles clicking off more than 33,000 admissions.

DUBLIN, April 17. -- A scientist searching this country for the "typical Irishman" is finding his task almost as difficult as that of the King's messengers who were told to hunt for a happy man's shirt.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- Net income of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad in 1933 was $8,523,433 compared with a deficit of $287,942 in 1932. This was disclosed today in the annual report of H.A. Scandrett, president, to stockholders.
Boat captains of the Great South Bay fleet believe that certain conditions harmful to fishing within the bay and in Fire Island Inlet can be remedied.

The Silk Textile Code Authority will become a corporation, it was announced yesterday by Peter Van Horn, chairman of the authority. He has instructed attorneys to proceed with the formalities preliminary to incorporation.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Complete withdrawal of American official participation in the government of Haiti was in sight tonight at the close of the conference between President Roosevelt and Stenio Vincent, Haitian President.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The average of wholesale commodity prices rose during March one-tenth of one point to 73.7 per cent of the 1926 average of 100, as compared with 73.6 per cent for February, Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department announced today.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- The secrets of our sleep-regulating mechanism, uncovered in part by reverting fullgrown dogs to a state of puppyhood in the laboratories of the University of Chicago, were told today before the convention of the American College of Physicians.

ALBANY, April 17. -- Striking back at criticism of the proposed Federal Child Labor Amendment, a group of organizations favoring the amendment filed a brief here today with the Senate Judiciary Committee in a plea for ratification.

Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris and E.D. Bogoljubow of Triberg, Germany, who are due to resume play in their world's championship chess match in Germany today, played unusually exciting chess in their second game at Baden-Baden. The champion, who won after thirty-seven moves, was the aggressor in a Queen's Pawn opening.

The power of Code Authorities to enforce compliance with code provisions and the right of industry to govern itself under the National Recovery Act were upheld yesterday. The decision by Federal Judge Francis J. Caffey was in an injunction suit brought by the William F. Chiniquy Company of Chicago and against the Code Authority of the Millinery Industry.
WASHINGTON, April 17. -- By the action of Vice President Garner today in breaking a tie vote, the Senate was forced into consideration of Senator Borah's anti-politicallawyer bill.

New York City will call soon for sealed bids on a new issue of $245,000 of fifty-year corporate stock, according to an announcement yesterday by Controller Cunningham. The proceeds are required for the purchase of premises necessary for an extension of the Interborough Parkway in the boroughs of Brooklyn and Queens.
One hundred and thirty-five athletes and managers of sports teams at Columbia have been named as insignia recipients, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Reynolds Benson.

George Jessel, stage comedian, said yesterday that he was engaged to marry Norma Talmadge, former motion picture star. Mr. Jessel made the announcement shortly after Miss Talmadge arrived from the West Coast with her Mexican divorce from Joseph M. Schenck, motion picture producer.

The Jersey City Commission suspended the liquor licenses of seventy-eight dealers yesterday and revoked one license after Thomas J. Wolfe, Director of Public Safety, reported that all had violated the "nip" ordinance. That local law, sponsored by Mayor Frank Hague, provides that all liquor dispensed for consumption on the premises shall be sold only in one and two ounce bottles.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- More than 100 Texas publishers and business men who arrived here on a special train this morning as part of an Eastern tour to acquaint the United States with the Lone Star State crowded into the President's office and heard Mr. Roosevelt describe the force Texas exercises in national politics.
The revolt against John F. Curry as leader of Tammany appeared last night to be on the verge of success.

While attempting to walk on the large supporting cable at a point where it curves low to the pedestrian's walk on the Williamsburg Bridge; Albert Duvinski, 17 years old, of 94 India Street, Brooklyn, fell to the trolley tracks thirty feet below about 10 o'clock last night and was killed.

CHICAGO, April 17. -- Packers were active buyers of hogs today after prices had dropped 10 cents a hundred weight from yesterday's level. Supplies were in excess of trade requirements, but a good clean-up was effected. The top was down 10 cents at $4, while the day's average dropped a like amount to $3.80.

As protests began to pile up yesterday against the Mayor's plan for a tax of one-twentieth of 1 per cent of the income of all businesses in excess of $10,000 a year, Mayor LaGuardia said it might be possible to cut the tax to one-thirtieth or one-fortieth of 1 per cent.

The Railroad Credit Corporation will be able to return about 50 per cent of the $75,000,000 contributed to its loan pool, according to an estimate published in the report of the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad for 1933. This sum was obtained from the proceeds of the emergency freight surcharges from Jan. 4, 1932, to March 31, 1933.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., April 17. -- The necessity of providing the very best equipment of a protective nature to resist the efforts of bandits was stressed in an emphatic manner before the session of the executive council of the American Bankers Association this afternoon.
Referring to the agitation in Washington about the bill to authorize the President to negotiate reciprocal tariff duties, I am under the impression that the cart is being put before the horse.
ALBANY, April 17. -- Leaders of the Legislature held a conference tonight in an attempt to reach a final decision as to whether they will seek to enact a permanent liquor control system this year.

It is painful to notice that Governor LANGER of North Dakota, a Nonpartisan friend of the farmer, has been indicted with certain other patriots of that State for violation of the law prohibiting assessment of Federal officeholders for political purposes, and for trying to obstruct the operation of an act of Congress.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- President Roosevelt was represented today as favoring the Glass amendment to the stock exchange control bill, providing for an independent commission with power to regulate margin requirements, and also Senator McAdoo's suggestion that the new commission take over administration of the 1933 Securities Act from the Federal Trade Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- An effort by the administration to have deleted from the revenue bill some of the outright increases voted by the Senate was forecast today as the measure was sent to conference by both houses.
" Stevedore," a new play by Paul Peters and George Sklar, will be presented this evening by the Theatre Union at the Civic Repertory Theatre.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17. -- Harvard's naval forces are closing the ranks split wide open by graduation. In his fifth year as head coach, Charley Whiteside is putting together almost from scratch a new varsity boat.

ATLANTA, April 17 (AP). -- The Southern Association's thirty-fourth annual season began today with New Orleans, last year's champion, getting off to a winning start with a 6-to-3 triumph over Birmingham.

Keyes Winter, appointed last week as a municipal court justice to fill the vacancy caused by the death of President-Justice William Chilvers, was inducted yesterday at the Ninth District Municipal Court, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

New York is passing, "if it has not already passed," the danger point raised by the deficiency in the 1934 budget," Joseph A. McGoldrick, Deputy Controller, disclosed last night at a dinner of the management division of the Real Estate Board in the Hotel Astor.
Your editorial "Bank Losses" is excellent as far as it goes, and it represents some slants of a viewpoint.
WASHINGTON, April 17. -- An offer by the National City Bank of New York to sell the National Bank of Haiti, a subsidiary, to the Haitian Government, is under consideration by the State Department.

Within the last few months consolidation of various local government units in various parts of the metropolitan area has been proposed as a means of economy. There has been the suggestion to unite the four Oranges in Essex County, N.J.; to consolidate Bayonne and other cities with Jersey City, and to consolidate various adjoining villages in Westchester County, N.Y.

The National Recovery Administration intervened yesterday without success in its effort to lift the stoppage ordered by the United Association of Dress Manufacturers, Inc., the contractors' organization in the dress industry, in protest against alleged violations of the dress code and collective agreement by the jobbers.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP). -- President Roosevelt gave forty minutes today to a study of the McLeod bill to pay off in full depositors in banks that have closed in the last four years.

Shoe merchants were urged to abandon price cutting and to substitute quality merchandising by speakers yesterday at the concluding session of the joint style conference of the National Shoe Retailers Association and Tanners Council of America at the Hotel Astor.

Police Commissioner O'Ryan and Mayor Joseph F. Loehr of Yonkers were among the character witnesses yesterday for John C. Hoenninger, 57 years old, a lawyer, who is being tried for the theft of $9,000 from Mrs. Josephine Erlwein, elderly widow of a physician, when Hoenninger was her attorney, in 1929.

About 400 executives of department stores in the metropolitan area gathered last night at a dinner conference in Gimbel's department store and discussed various phases and problems of their industry. It was one of the largest meetings of its kind.

SCARCELY a month goes by, these days, without some one writing to this department in quest of a good introduction to Karl Marx. We have never known what to recommend. Marxism, in a hundred years of First, Second, Third (and now a Trotskyite Fourth?) Internationals, has created such a conflicting number of doctrines, there have been so many "revisions" and "heresies," that it is virtually impossible to discover an introduction that is trustworthy

The intimation in dispatches from Tokyo yesterday that the Japanese would seek to discourage the sale of foreign aircraft and accessories to China was read with interest here by representatives of companies whose exports to Asia, mainly to China, totaled $2,763,533 in 1933.

In his testimony before the House Ways and Means Committee in March on the bill to give the President power to make reciprocal tariff agreements, Secretary WALLACE said that "fair warning should be given" to "inefficient industries." They should be treated with consideration.

BERLIN, April 17. -- Rudolf Hess, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's deputy in the Nazi party, today established a censorship without whose approval no book or other publication may hereafter be lawfuly offered to the public as "National Socialist."

The annual luncheon and meeting of the Women's Division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, which will be held tomorrow at the Hotel Commodore, will be followed by a symposium on "Social Work Under the New Deal."
The Longwood Bowl tournament conducted for years as a July tennis fixture, will be held this season starting Aug. 6, it was learned yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Hendrick Vanderbilt Duryea gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Arnall P. Hodges, Mr. and Mrs. Clarence F. Busch, Mr. and Mrs. William Rhoder and William G. Chipley.

BATON ROUGE, La., April 17 (AP). -- With only twenty-three precincts missing in the Sixth District Congressional primary, J.Y. Sanders Jr., anti-Huey Long candidate, held a lead of more than 1,700 votes over his nearest opponent, Harry D. Wilson, Commissioner of Agriculture in the Long-Allen State administration, but complete returns will be necessary to determine whether a second primary must be called to settle the contest.

A group of prominent musicians gave their views on what they would do with $1,000,000 if they were asked to use this amount for the benefit of music, at a luncheon of the National Music League at Sherry's yesterday. The opinions ran from the proper instruction of music supervisors in the schools of the United States to the establishment of opera companies and orchestras in every State in the country.
PARIS, April 17. -- France's stand on armaments has been set forth in a note to Great Britain, which was approved unanimously by the Cabinet this morning.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- A "treaty-strength navy" and an "efficient" army, modernized as recommended by General Douglas MacArthur, were demanded in resolutions adopted today by the Daughters of the American Revolution.

Former Governor William E. Sweet of Colorado, speaking as the official representative of General Hugh S. Johnson, NRA Administrator, retorted yesterday to Dr. William A. Wirt, who has expressed fears of a revolution. He agreed that a real revolution was taking place, but asserted that it was a peaceful, economic revolution and "within the framework of the profit system."

Bonds on the New York Stock Exchange regained yesterday some of the ground lost on Monday, except United States Government long-term issues, which moved down generally and ended 5-32 lower to 1-32 point higher. Trading aggregated $14,518,000, against $17,443,600 on the previous day.

TRENTON, April 17. -- Of seventy candidates whose names will appear either on the Democratic or Republican ballot at the primary elections May 15 for nomination as United States Senator, Governor or Representative, fourteen are seeking another term.

Diplomas to 396 graduates of the school department of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of the City of New York were presented last night at the closing exercises of the school at Town Hall. George E. Hoe prizes were awarded to thirty-nine graduates. Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, delivered the address.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 17. -- Seamen as well as passengers on German ships docking in the port of New York have brought in "vast quantities of Nazi propaganda literature," Assemblyman Samuel Pesin said in an interview tonight. He added that some of this literature had reached Hudson County.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Now that the Johnson bill restricting American public and private loans has become law, many people who paid no attention to it on its way through Congress are wringing their hands. For if the Department of Justice shall take a narrow view of the provisions of this remarkable measure, this government and its citizens will be able to make loans to Finland -- and nowhere else.

The Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, which took $350,000 of a $1,029,000 bond issue of White Plains, and the remainder on a sixty-day option, reported yesterday it had orders for $60,000 of the Unsold portion of the issue. City officials were cheered by the report and expressed confidence that the entire issue would sell.

An investigation of the Municipal Sanitarium at Otisville, N.Y., now being carried on by Dr. Alfred E. Shipley, deputy Hospitals Commissioner, is merely a part of a general survey of the entire Hospitals Department, Commissioner S.S. Goldwater said yesterday.

The forty-fifth annual exhibition of the New York Water-Color Club will open in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Building at 8:30 this evening with a private view, and to the public tomorrow, continuing until May 3. Alphaeus P. Cole is president of this organization, which devotes its attention not alone to water-color but also to work in black and white.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation in the past four weeks has paid to the city $1,151,933 in taxes for distressed mortgagors, and for the week ended April 13 paid $325,234 in back taxes on dwellings here, Vincent Dailey, State manager, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- Reports of dissatisfaction in Moscow over the decision of the trustees of the Export-Import Bank to withhold credits from exporters wishing to do business with the Soviet Government impressed officials today as the result of a misunderstanding.
SCIMITAR VALLEY, B.C., April 10. -- After a 7,000-mile journey the Norman Watson Expedition is now at the scene of its objective, the Mount Waddington group of British Columbia's Coast Range.

A string of twenty-four ponies, to be used by the representatives of the East in the national indoor polo championships starting Saturday night in Chicago, will head West today in a special car attached to the Commodore Vanderbilt Express.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP). -- The Detroit Tigers made Mickey Cochrane's managerial debut a success today by opportune use of six hits to defeat Chicago, 8 to 3, in the American League opener here before 18,000 spectators.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 17. -- John R. Buchanan's Chatmoss turned in a sparkling performance in the mile and seventy yards of the featured Harewood Purse at Havre de Grace today to score by two lengths. W.I. Newmarch's Hokuao was second, four, lengths ahead of the Anall Stable's Larranaga, which was making his first start in eight months.

Not improbably, this is what happened to Dr. WIRT. Having taken exclusive control of the dinner conversation for the space of three or four hours, it occurred to him at the end that perhaps he should have given some one else a chance.

ALBANY, April 17. -- The Crawford-Breitenbach bill to permit open betting at the New York tracks, long sought by racing enthusiasts, was passed in slightly amended form by both houses of the Legislature today.

OTTAWA, April 17 (Canadian Press). -- The Board of Railway Commissioners today made public a judgment revising the railway rates on newsprint from Canadian mills to centres in the United States. This judgment is the outcome of applications made to the board in 1929 by various newsprint producers in Canada.

The stewards of The Jockey Club moved yesterday to clear the decks for the opening of the metropolitan racing season on Saturday by appointing officials, licensing jockeys and trainers and disposing of other matters of business, William Woodward, chairman of The Jockey Club, presided at the meeting.

Increases in newspaper circulation and advertising over the country in the last few months tell a story of business upturn. These figures, one index to trade conditions, show that, in the wake of increased employment, trade is on the increase.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The drive to force silver legislation through this session of Congress has not lessened despite the known opposition of President Roosevelt to the pending legislation making remonetization of silver mandatory.

Moderate recoveries were made by most staples yesterday except metal futures, which lacked trend. Hopes were expressed in some circles again that the silver bloc might win over the President to "helpful'' legislation at tomorrow's conference, but commodity dealers generally were not confident.

Denouncing the policies of the New Deal as "ominous," "bullying," "bulldozing" and "reactionary," Colonel Theodore Roosevelt caustically criticized the administration of his distant cousin, the President, last night in an address to the National Republican Club.
The allotment of Summer dates for boxing and wrestling in the metropolitan area was made yesterday at a meeting of the New York State Athletic Commission.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., April 17. -One of the wildest chases ever recorded in Westchester traffic history took place today when Motorcycle Officer Dennis Dorgan of the East Chester town police pursued John Chaplick, 27 years old, of New Haven, Conn., for more than ten miles in a circuitous route from here to the Bronx.

As a result of the activity in grains, the share market occupied a secondary position yesterday, as it did on the day before. Trading on the Stock Exchange was conducted more cautiously than usual and the total volume was only 945,000 shares.

Curtailment of a number of activities of the Health Department, chiefly hygiene and baby health station work, is necessary in view of the drastic reduction in the department personnel voted by the Board of Estimate as part of the city's economy program, it was indicated yesterday. Publication in The City Record of the list of 436 jobs abolished shows that the axe fell heaviest upon the medical and nursing staffs.
Johnny Goodman, national open golf champion, was guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon held at the Advertising Club of New York.

ALBANY, April 17. -- Governor Lehman won a signal victory in the Assembly this afternoon when, despite Republican control of that body, five of the bills in his public utility reform program were passed by wholly unexpected majorities. Action on the sixth was deferred until tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The reported draft of a statement of Japan's Chinese policy drew no comment in official circles today. Unofficially, the project appeared to observers as another step in the recent Japanese program of clarifying and forcing to an issue outstanding questions between the United States and Japan.

ALBANY, April 17. -- Three of Governor Lehman's budget bills were passed today by the Assembly as both houses plowed through heavy calendars in an effort to bring about final adjournment Friday night.
The Fonda, Johnstown Gloversville Railroad reported as follows for March and the first three months of the year:

BUENOS AIRES, April 17. -- Coincident with the Bolivian claims of a sweeping victory in the Chaco warfare, Argentine newspapers are giving prominence to two incidents capable of involving this country in a serious dispute with Bolivia.

ST. LOUIS, April 17 (AP). -- The St. Louis Cardinals today unleashed a resounding batting attack, drove two pitchers to cover, defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates 7 to 1 and showed the critics they were to be reckoned with in the 1934 pennant chase.
THE TIMES published a news item of the disapproval by the legislative committee of the New York County Lawyers Association of the Byrne bill for compulsory unemployment insurance.

MOSCOW, April 17. -- Warning that the Johnson act may prevent any considerable Soviet purchases of American goods until after the end of the second five-year plan -- 1937 -- was given today in For Industrialization, the official organ of heavy industry here.
ALBANY, April 17. -- Mayor LaGuardia won assurances from the legislative leaders today that a measure would be passed to permit the city administration to levy new taxes to balance its budget.
NORWALK, Conn., April 17 (AP). -- Two strange men were introduced tonight in the Bell Island mystery of how Arthur Todd met his death in Long Island Sound.
LONDON, April 17. -- The British income tax remains by far the highest in the world, even with the 10 per cent reduction announced today.
An industrial deal in the Bronx, together with housing and business property transactions in that borough and Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, made up the urban realty activity reported yesterday.

German-Americans should in self-protection join the counter-boycott against those who boycott German goods, more than 3,500 persons were told last night at a meeting of the League of the Friends of New Germany, held at the Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street.

The proposed new law will do away with a system of betting which has prevailed since 1913. It has been hypocritical in the extreme, but it has been a legal system. It has been unpopular with the public, awkward in its workings and has for years caused devotees of racing to say that a change must come.

HARRISBURG, Pa., April 17. -- A platform of thirteen pledges, one of which is "to support the New Deal in the interest of the plain people," was made public today by Governor Pinchot, candidate against Senator Reed for the Republican Senatorial nomination at the May primary.

NEWARK, N.J., April 17. -- With a new manager at the helm and many changes in the line-up, the Newark Bears will open their baseball season against, the champion Buffalo Bisons tomorrow in an International League game at Ruppert Stadium.
WASHINGTON, April 17. -President Roosevelt conferred with President Vincent of Haiti on the mutual problems of their countries and with Senator Wagner on the Labor Disputes Bill.

HAVANA, April 17. -- Two thousand prisoners will be freed under a decree, signed tonight by President Mendieta, granting amnesty to violators of the prohibition against strikes. Many imprisoned workers have gone on hunger strikes.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 17. -- The Princeton baseball team defeated an alumni nine, 4 -- 2, on University Field today. Goose Gosnell and Johnny Reichel allowed the Alumni four hits and issued only one base on balls in the best Tiger pitching exhibition of the year.

Denial that the chief German lines were assisting in circulating a new publication designed by the Nazis to gain support in America was made yesterday by H. Muhlenbrock, passenger traffic manager of the Hamburg-American Line-North German Lloyd. He said in a statement:

Twenty parcels offered at foreclosure auctions in Manhattan and the Bronx were bid in by the respective plaintiffs yesterday. Eight of the holdings were in the former borough and twelve in the latter. The larger parcels were five-story tenement houses.
CLEVELAND, April 17 (AP). -- With Earl Averill setting the pace with a home run and a double, the Indians opened the 1934 baseball season by defeating the Browns before 21,000 fans today, 5 to 2.

CHICAGO, April 17 -- New low levels for the season were established today for all deliveries of corn, oats and barley and for September wheat on the Board of Trade as the result of a general rush of liquidating sales. May wheat dropped more than 3 cents to 76 7/8 cents a bushel, the lowest price since Oct. 17, when it touched 71 1/2 cents.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 17. -- The Princeton baseball team defeated an alumni nine, 4 -- 2, on University Field today. Goose Gosnell and Johnny Reichel allowed the Alumni four hits and issued only one base on balls in the best Tiger pitching exhibition of the year.

Denial that the chief German lines were assisting in circulating a new publication designed by the Nazis to gain support in America was made yesterday by H. Muhlenbrock, passenger traffic manager of the Hamburg-American Line-North German Lloyd. He said in a statement:

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP). -- The defense of Bishop James Cannon Jr. was started late today after the churchman's counsel had failed to obtain from Justice Peyton Gordon a directed verdict of not guilty.

Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Dore reserved decision yesterday in the suit of minority stockholders of the National City Bank against the directors for an accounting of $70,000,000 alleged to have been lost through negligence and improper acts.

The recent sale of a Houdon bust of Thomas Jefferson to the Boston Museum of Fine Arts for $40,000 resulted in an attachment granted in the Supreme Court yesterday against the property of Jean Soufrice, Paris art dealer, including the proceeds of the sale.

LONDON, April 17. -- For the third time Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, presented to Parliament today a budget in which no provision is made for payment of anything to the United States on account of the war debt.

MADRID, April 17. -- Premier Alejandro Lerroux today accepted the resignation of Minister of Justice Alvarez Valdes and asked Salvador de Madariaga, Minister of Education, to fill this Cabinet vacancy temporarily without releasing his own portfolio.
MARSE JOE McCARTHY was preparing to herd his Yankee troops in the general direction of Philadelphia and paused to distribute a few well-chosen words on baseball in general and one item in particular.

Democratic members of the Board of Aldermen expressed their displeasure yesterday with the recent activities of Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard by voting down a resolution which commended him for his work.

The New York Infirmary for Women and Children was the beneficiary of the third "gala Tuesday evening" held last night at the Casino de Paree. Like its two predecessors, the entertainment was featured by a special program, one of the highlights of which was an auction of masques of several prominent women of society.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Edward F. Corsi of New York, former Commissioner of Immigration at Ellis Island, addressed the Daughters of the American Revolution today, bringing a message from the foreign-born citizens of the country.

PARIS, April 18. -- On the basis of its results upon wine and liquor exports for the first quarter of this year, the lifting of prohibition in the United States has been definitely disappointing to French dealers.

MANNHEIM, Germany, April 18. -- The Hakenkreuz Banner, the Nazi newspaper of Mannheim, today characterized the storming of the publication office of the Neue Mannheimer Volksblatt as a "spontaneous" expression of the indignation among the citizens of Mannheimer that the Volksblatt, still daring to represent itself as a "Catholic newspaper," should, have made appeals for Catholic readers on that ground.

Encouraged by word from Washington that definite plans for obtaining $132,000,000 in Federal loans and grants could now proceed, the LaGuardia administration drove ahead yesterday on its task of balancing the budget in order to qualify for the Federal funds.

Following the adoption of a resolution by the Board of Aldermen last Tuesday authorizing a survey aimed at revision of the city's licensing system, Bernard S. Deutsch, president of the board, named a committee of four yesterday to make the survey.

An editorial in the April 19 issue of Advance, the national weekly organ of the Congregational and Christian Churches in America, criticizes Dr. Hugh S. Magill, general secretary of the International Council of Religious Education, for accepting the presidency of the American Federation of Utility Investors, Inc., of Chicago, Ill.

BERLIN, April 18. -- The official Diplomatisch-Politische Correspondenz characterizes the French arms note to Britain as an evasion of the real issue and a sabotaging of all efforts at disarmament by raising new and unjustified charges against Germany.

Dress contractors of the United Association of Dress Manufacturers, engaged in the wholesale stoppage ordered by the association last Monday, were instructed yesterday to call off the stoppage immediately as irregular and unjustified. The order was made in a decision by Adolph Feldblum, impartial chairman of the industry, on a complaint filed with him against the contractors by the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union.

ARLINGTON, Texas, April 18. -- Jockey W. D. (Wayne) Wright, runner-up to Jack Westrope for national riding honors last year, held the centre of the stage at Arlington Downs today by booting home four winners.

I applaud heartily the spirit in which your editorial "Students and War" is written. While I personally believe the causes of war to be far deeper and more fundamental than those you cite, it is most certainly vital that these causes be investigated by youth.

GENEVA, April 18. -- Alarm over the "disastrous effects" of the depression upon youth everywhere is strongly expressed in the draft of a report which the League of Nations child welfare committee has made public.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., April 18. -- The colors of J.W.Y. Martin were carried to victory in the featured Combat Purse at Havre de Grace today when the 3-year-old Law Suit scored easily, winning by three lengths over the Brookmead Stable's National Anthem in the six furlong dash.
CHICAGO, April 18 (AP). -- A pair of homers by Outfielders Goose Goslin and Gerry Walker scored five runs today and gave the Detroit Tigers a second straight victory over the White Sox, 6 to 5.

CINCINNATI, April 18 (AP). -- Led by Chuck Klein, who hammered his second home run in two days, and Pitcher Guy Bush, who managed to baffle most of the Cincinnati batsmen, the Chicago Cubs took their second game from the Reds today, 8 to 4.

A Madonna and Child," assigned to Niccola Rondinelli and Giovanni Bellini, brought $2,000 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at a sale of paintings from the Ehrich Galleries. The buyer was an agent. The painting bears the studio inscription of the Bellini atelier and is thought by the auction galleries to have been retouched by Bellini himself.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- The neutron, one of the latest sub-atomic articles added to the physicist's stock in trade, is believed by scientists of the Bartol Research Foundation to be an intermediary agent which helps cosmic rays break up the atoms of substances through which they pass.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The special House committee which investigated the charges of a brain-trust revolutionary plot in the government, which were made by Dr. William A. Wirt, Gary educator, decided by a strict party vote of 3 to 2 today not to go further in the inquiry.

PARIS, April 18 (AP). -- The sensational charge that Leon Trotsky plotted for a revolutionary dictatorship in France through the fatal February street riots was disclosed by authorities today as the exiled former Red Army leader hunted vainly for another refuge.
LONDON, April 18. -- The engagenent of Basil Dean, theatrical producer to Miss Victoria Hopper, a star in the Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical show, "Three Sisters," has been announced.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 18. -- The Twomey resolution for a constitutional amendment to permit the use of pari-mutuel machines at the New York race tracks was passed in the Assembly tonight by a vote of 106 to 36.

One of the largest programs of new industrial financing since the passage of the Securities Act of 1933 will be undertaken next week when public offering will be made of 325,000 shares of common stock of the Glenn L. Martin Company, airplane manufacturer, of Baltimore, Md.

CHICAGO, April 18. -- A new theory that infantile paralysis sufferers might have been spared physical impairment if they had experienced an attack of typhoid fever or dysentery a year before the virus of the disease entered their systems was presented today before the American College of Physicians, in convention here.

COUNT WILCZEK, whose reminiscences, edited by his daughter, Elizabeth, Countess Kinsky, are published under the title of "Gentleman of Vienna" (Reynal Hitchcock, $3), leaves us somewhat perplexed. In his more garrulous moments he reminds us of one of Peter Arno's mustachioed Cadwalladers, sitting beneath the moose heads and the mounted salmon and recalling the grand old days of yore, to the infinite delight of his cronies and the infinite boredom of the young.

BUENOS AIRES, April 18. -- The report of the Bank of the Nation for March, published today, indicates that the Argentine Grain Board has accumulated a stock of more than 110,000,000 bushels of wheat. It says the board's debit balance at the end of March was 16,091,848 pesos, compared with 8,738,052 at the end of February and 3,553,279 at the end of January.

ATHENS, April 18. -- The sudden outbreak of a railway strike as a result of a new workers' insurance law paralyzed the Greek railway system today, and at the same time great excitement was caused by rumors of an impending dictatorial coup.
May we ask those who have a thought and a heart to help the forgotten children of the forgotten group in the forgotten sections of this city to get a little Summer camping?

The probability that Herbert Bayard Swope of the Long Island Park Commission would be a member of the proposed new State Racing Commission loomed yesterday as racing plans swept on toward the opening of the season on Saturday.

A new issue of $520,000 Suffolk County (N. Y.) bonds, dated May 1, 1934, and due from 1935 to 1959, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate headed by Estabrook Co. and including Phelps, Fenn Co. and Graham, Parsons Co., which topped twelve other bidders.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered further yesterday, sending the list 30 points above the low marks of Tuesday before scattered reselling left quotations at net gains of 2 to 3 points.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Postoffice Department was prepared tonight to proceed on Friday with the examination of bids for temporary operation of air mail routes, ignoring the injunction proceedings filed today in the District of Columbia Supreme Court in behalf of four subsidiaries of United Aircraft and Transport, Inc.
Auctioneers put up thirteen Manhattan and Bronx parcels of real estate at foreclosure auctions yesterday. All the properties were bought in by the plaintiffs. One scheduled sale was adjourned.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The National Labor Board condemned today the action of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company of New York in "discriminating" against union workers and upheld the course followed by the New York Regional Board in seeking an adjustment of the dispute between the company and those of its employes who are members of the Amalgamated Association of Street and Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes.

The outlook for democracy is brighter than a month ago. Here at home people may still differ on just how narrowly President ROOSEVELT escaped being supplanted by a dictator, but even those who viewed with alarm will concede that things are much better since Dr. WIRT let the light into hitherto dark places.

Bronx property owners and representatives of civic associations joined yesterday in heckling Public Service Commissioner George R. Van Namee while he was conducting another of the series of public hearings on rates charged for gas supplied by the Bronx Gas and Electric Company.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- President Roosevelt began a personal study of the rail wage controversy and expressed opposition to the McLeod bill to pay depositors in closed banks.

Two years ago last October three youths armed with pistols invaded the home of Barron G. Collier, advertising man and an honorary deputy police commissioner, at 8 East Seventy-fifth Street, during the absence of the family. They ripped out a small wall safe containing jewelry and valuable papers and carried it away.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Clarence Darrow, chairman of President Roosevelt's NRA Board of Review, indicated today that his board would dissolve when its report was made to the President on Saturday.

With the exception of rubber and cottonseed oil futures, trading in commodities was mixed in trend yesterday, and the close found prices only slightly changed on either side. Quotations in the cash markets also were irregular.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 19. -The Foreign Office declaration on China fell among the diplomatic corps like a bombshell and it is taken for granted the foreign governments will seek a clarification of Japan's claims, though the form in which they were announced will render the task difficult.
ANDOVER, Mass., April 18. -- St. John's Prep nine swamped Andover's team today, 17 -- 3, behind a barrage of extra-base hits.

HAVANA, April 18. -- Two men were wounded this morning by the explosion of a bomb in the Central Postoffice. The bomb wrecked a section of the ground floor of the building and injured Carlos Valdes and Eladio Perez, postal employes. This is the second explosion that has occurred in the postoffice during the past month.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 18 (AP). -- Blood was spilled in the Alabama coal fields today as 21,000 miners remained idle, and troops of the National Guard were mobilized when ominous threats were heard in some of the strife-torn areas of Jefferson County.

The Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation has sold to a banking group $5,583,000 of the first and refunding 6 per cent mortgage bonds, Series A, due 1968, of its wholly owned subsidiary, the New York Rapid Transit Corporation, according to an announcement yesterday by G.M. Dahl, chairman, after a special meeting of directors.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- "The Fleet's In," a picture representing uniformed sailors on shore liberty and painted by Paul Cadmus, New York CWA artist, was removed from the Navy Department today at the insistence of Secretary Swanson.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- A total of $500,000,000 will be spent on public works under the relief and recovery program for the fiscal year beginning July 1, according to decisions made today during a conference between President Roosevelt and Secretary Ickes.

Business in the money market remained at a standstill so far as new ventures were concerned. About all that went on represented replacements. Quotations for all classes continued steady and unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent, while 3/4 per tent prevailed in the Street market.

In its twenty-fourth annual report to stockholders the Cities Service Company reports for 1933 consolidated net earnings of $59,784,932 before depletion, depreciation and replacements. This compares with $60,951,583 for the previous year, a decline of 2 per cent.

A ninth-inning uprising that netted two runs enabled the University Pennsylvania to pull ahead to a 9-8 victory yesterday over the champion Eastern Intercollegiate League Columbia nine at Baker Field. It was the opening league contest of the year for both tenm and, although early in the campaign, the effect of Penn's triumph is important.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Boston Maine Railroad was authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission today to issue $16,340,000 of 7 per cent prior preference stock to be exchanged for a like amount of its outstanding mortgage bonds at the rate of five shares of stock for each $500 of bonds.
ALBANY, April 18. -- After being assailed as a "brain child of Wall Street," a bill to permit branch banking was passed in the Assembly today, 92 to 59.

ST. LOUIS, April 18 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates batted Paul Dean, younger brother of the celebrated Dizzy, out of the box in two innings today, continued the attack against his three successors, and defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 7 to 6.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., April 18. -- The executive council of the American Bankers Association, meeting here today, heard a review of the operation of the Federal deposit insurance in a report of its head, Leo T. Crowley, as read by L.E. Birdzell.

Anticlimax ruled the arena at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, leering clownishly at the press box, as "John Curry" and "Fiorello" met with what was supposed to have been the shock of contending armies, in Clyde Beatty's "Big Cage" act.

Gloria Swanson will make her first Broadway stage appearance at the Paramount for the week beginning tomorrow. She will be seen in a short comedy piece written by George Height and produced under the supervision of Edmund Goulding.

More than 100 buyers of retail stores all over the country have already affiliated with the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday by T.L. Blanke, managing director. He added that it is now the policy of the group to appoint buyers to the various merchandising committees.

Reorganization of the handling of non-athletic student activities at Columbia University has been voted by the University Council, it was announced yesterday by The Columbia Spectator, student dally newspaper of Columbia College.
Pete Blumette allowed only six hits as the Manhattan College baseball team handed the St. John's University nine its first setback of the season by a 6-to-2 score at Dexter Park yesterday.

Need for continued existence of such welfare organizations as the Salvation Army is greater with business conditions improving than at the height of the depression, Bayard F. Pope, chairman of the finance committee of the Charity Organization Society and formerly executive vice chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, declared yesterday.

The use of a species of small fish of Central Europe in the diagnosis of a type of cancer was disclosed last night by Dr. Russell S. Ferguson, who is in charge of the urological laboratories of Memorial Hospital, 2 West 106th Street.

Edna St. Vincent Millay, who is due back from Europe in a week or two, probably will bring back the manuscript for a new book of poetry which will be published by Harpers in the Fall. The title will be, "Epitaph for the Race of Man."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 18. -- The oarsmen of Massachusetts Institute of Technology are working twice a day now from the boathouse at the head of the Charles River course. The veteran Bill Haines, one of the great figures of rowing, is driving from the head of his coaching launch and feels that the men working with him have better prospects by a considerable margin, than the crew of the past season.
PARIS, April 18. -- It is with all the gravity of a "political act of capital importance" that the French note to Britain is regarded here, and it is so described in tonight's press.

The Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics announces a change in its method of computing data on employment and payrolls. Hitherto its regular monthly index has used 1926 as a base -- that is, the conditions prevailing in that year have been taken as the norm, and the index computed for that year has represented 100 on a scale recording later changes.
WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Following is the revised bill, approved by the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee, to provide Federal Stock Exchange regulation:

A letter to the Board of Estimate requesting an appropriation of $150,000 to enable the Park Department to begin building the water, light and sewer systems and other facilities in Fort Tryon Park was made public yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.
ALBANY, April 18. -- Aided by bolting Democrats, the Republicans in the Senate threw Governor Lehman's budget out of balance today.

Methods of improving motion pictures were discussed yesterday at a forum on "the arts" conducted by the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor. Poetry, design, music and other topics also were discussed by representatives of these branches during the morning and afternoon sessions.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 18 (AP). -The Syracuse Chiefs opened their new municipal stadium with a 2-to-1 victory over the Montreal Royals today as 10,000 fans turned out to welcome the return of International League baseball after an absence of six years.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 18. -- Providence College hit hard and timely in the pinches and displayed a stout defense to blank the Army nine today by 9 to 0. Blanche let the Cadets down with half a dozen scattered blows and fanned nine. He also made three hits, including a triple.

CLEVELAND, April 18 (AP). -Timely hitting by Puccinelli, Campbell and Mellilo gave the St. Louis Browns two runs in the ninth inning and a shut-out victory over the Cleveland Indians today. The Indians won yesterday's opener.

Governor LEHMAN has had his way with the utility bills. Their passage is in part a tribute to his own vigorous leadership, and especially to the effective way in which he called upon his Democratic followers to redeem their campaign pledges. But obviously that is not the whole story.

To those who feel that John Singleton Copley (1737-1815) is second to none in the roster of early American portrait painters, the excellent impression made by this artist's work in the group of pictures from the Ehrich Galleries, now being auctioned, may well prove a source of satisfaction.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Cabinet committee named to study price changes and policies and their effect upon the recovery program will probably report Friday to President Roosevelt. An important contribution to the controversy in progress over NRA codes and agreements under the Agricultural Adjustment Administration is expected.

BERLIN, April 18. -- The sagging trend on the Boerse noticeable in the last few days, turned into a slump today, affecting both stocks and fixed-interest securities. Losses in the stock market ranged in some cases beyond 5 points, While in the bond market the new valorization loan lost 10 per cent of its value.
CHICAGO, April 18. -- Dr. Hugh S. Magill in a reply to the editorial in The Advance, issued today, said:

Matters relating to the selection and organization of a permanent Industrial Relations Board for the theatre, as projected in the revised legitimate theatre code, were discussed yesterday at the first meeting of the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority following the final hearings last week in Washington on the revised code.

PARIS, April 18. -- The Parisians are going to make Jean Chiappe, ousted Prefect of Police, a Deputy, Lieut. Col. Ferrandi, president of the National Union of Colonial Combatants, has told the parliamentary commission of inquiry into the riots of Feb. 6.

The city of Philadelphia is operating under a "budget of hope" and faces the possibility of a deficit at the end of the current fiscal year, Mayor J. Hampton Moore told members of the Municipal Bond Club of New York at a luncheon meeting yesterday.

Fearing the Legislature may adjourn before passing four emergency housing bills now before it, the Emergency Committee for Tenement Safety called a special meeting yesterday at 99 Park Avenue and urged delegates of 100 participating organizations to bombard Capitol Hill with telegrams, letters and telephone calls demanding immediate enactment of the measures.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- Officials of the Agriculture Adjustment Administration, from Secretary Wallace down, expressed misgivings today over the prospect of having to administer the Bankhead bill for compulsory cotton control, which passed the House of Representatives yesterday and is now awaiting the signature of the President.

Among the things which the world is recovering must be listed the "spokesman" for the Japanese Foreign Office. He was very active and vocal two and three years ago when some one had to explain what the Japanese Army was doing in Manchuria, what the attitude was of the Japanese Government toward the Washington treaties, toward the League of Nations, and other matters about which the public was mystified.

BERLIN, April 18. -- The German mark, like the Russian ruble, became a purely domestic currency today, when the government issued a decree prohibiting the removal from the country of any mark bills or domestic gold coin.

With pitiful frequency the daily press reports cases of individuals, or even whole families, discovered "starving" or "on the brink of starvation" in various parts of the city. Some of these unfortunates are found in their homes, others wandering shelterless in the streets.

BERLIN, April 18. -- Captain Ernst Roehm, Chief of Staff of the Nazi storm troops and Minister without portfolio, expressed his ideas about the National Socialist revolution and the need for the storm troops he commands to a gathering of about 1,000 persons at the Ministry of Propaganda today.

" There has been too much emphasis on nationality in fashion," Miss Selma Robinson declared in a short talk preceding a fashion show last night under the auspices of the Industrial Arts Exposition in Rockefeller Center. Miss Robinson conducted the showing of Spring and Summer fashions created by American designers, which included more than sixty costumes.
Included in Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday were resales of housing properties.
Three emperors were in town yesterday -- all emperors of golf.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., April 18. -- Melita II, a strong-going bay gelding, carrying the colors of the Flying Horse Farm, captured the featured Glenwood Steeplechase before a crowd of nearly 5,000 as the second day of racing brought the Middleburg Hunts to a close on the Sands Estate today.

PARIS, April 18. -- Attention was centered on France's internal armaments problem again today when Vice Admiral Schwerer, president of the Action Francaise League, and Maurice Pujo, editor-in-chief of the newspaper Action Francaise and the leader of the Camelots du Roi, both told a Parliamentary commission they had recommended that their members arm themselves.

Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. has bought examples of the work of nine little-known artists from the exhibition of the Salons of America, now in progress in Rockefeller Centre. The works were selected for Mrs. Rockefeller, who is now in Europe, by her son, Nelson.

With Bill Gottlieb, star left-hander, turning in his second consecutive masterful pitching performance, New York University's baseball team defeated Rutgers, 7 to 2, yesterday at Ohio Field. The veteran hurler, who opened the Violet season last Friday with a three-hit game against Manhattan, limited the losing team to a similar total.
Hack Wilson limped out of the dugout at Ebbets Field yesterday with two out, the tying run on second base and 8,000 fans yelling themselves hoarse for a Wilsonian home run.

More than high speed is involved in the case of the streamlined Burlington train which was driven by a 600-horsepower Diesel electric engine at 104 miles an hour in a trial run. As far back as May, 1893, the Empire State Express made a spurt of 112 miles an hour.

WARSAW, April 18. -- James G. McDonald, the League of Nations High Commissioner for German Refugees, has arrived here to investigate the situation of 30,000 Jewish refugees, of whom 95 per cent are Polish citizens who had lived in Germany from fifteen to twenty years.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- President Roosevelt began today a personal study of the wage dispute between railroads and employe organizations, surveying the roads' claims in an hour's discussion with the presidents of six large systems.

Charging that evidence of a "situation scandalous beyond description" in one of the guaranteed mortgage companies had been "kept secret" by the State Insurance Department, Samuel Untermyer wrote yesterday to George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, demanding that the latter make public this and other evidence immediately.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP). -Counsel for Bishop James Cannon Jr. moved today to put into the record of his trial evidence to show that the case had its inception in what was termed a "personal, malicious political attack" by Representative Tinkham of Massachusetts four years ago.

Textile High School's baseball team came from behind to defeat Theodore Roosevelt High, 7 to 4, yesterday at Bedford Park. It was the first Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond Division P.S.A.L. game of the season for both teams.
Lily Pons is singing tonight at the Westchester County Centre, White Plains, as her last appearance in the metropolitan area this season.

LONDON, April 18. -- The second French note in reply to the British Government's disarmament proposals on Jan. 29 was received in London today. It definitely puts an end to the bilateral negotiations in behalf of disarmament, which have been going on fruitlessly since Germany left the League of Nations in October, and declared the whole business must be transferred back to Geneva.

To many watchers of the business situation, the fall this week of more than 7 cents a bushel in the price of wheat, along with other grains, will bring a sense of disappointment; though it can hardly cause great surprise. For a year the market for wheat has been influenced by two independent and often conflicting considerations -the actual supply-and-demand position and the Government's action on the currency.

More than 11,000 Jewish refugees from Germany entered Palestine between April 1, 1933, and Jan. 1, 1934, it is revealed in a report on the Jewish National Home by Morris Rothenberg, president of the Zionist Organization of America. The Central Bureau for the Settlement of German Jews in Palestine, the report shows, spent $330,000 between October, 1933, and March, 1934, for various activities relating to the settlement of German Jews.
ALBANY, April 18. -- Both houses of the Legislature labored late tonight through heavy calendars in an effort to bring about final adjournment on Friday.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- New York City's expenditures for operation and maintenance of its general departments amounted in 1932 to $489,204,290, or $67.77 per capita, as against $65.48 in 1931 and $25.64 in 1917, according to financial statistics of the city corporation for the fiscal year ending Dec. 31, 1932, made public today by the Census Bureau.

MANILA, April 18. -- The general uneasiness here over the impending acceptance of the Tydings independence bill at the forthcoming session of the Legislature had changed to a state of outright alarm today as political groups and business communities saw blow after blow struck at the entire Philippine economic organization by Congressional leaders.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 18. -- By a strict party vote of 11 to 3 the Senate today adopted a resolution petitioning the United States Congress for statehood with the coalitionists favoring the measure and the Liberals opposing it, following a debate which lasted from midnight to dawn.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., April 18. -- Authority to control the chartering of banks by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was advocated tonight by the chairman of its board, Leo T. Crowley, whose address was read to the executive council of the American Bankers Association by L.E. Birdzell, general counsel of the corporation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 18. -An increase of revenue of more than $2,850,000 for the first quarter of 1934 was reported today to the stockholders of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad at the annual meeting. It was the first session in which complete harmony has reigned in nearly a quarter century.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- About 419,000 workers were returned to private industrial employment last month and weekly payrolls were increased by $12,904,000 over February, according to figures reported to the Bureau of Labor Statistics and made public today by Secretary Perkins of the Department of Labor.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- All the thrills that should have been supplied in yesterday's opening game here were crowded into today's second skirmish between the Yanks and the Athletics at Shibe Park for the benefit of about 5,000 fans.
For the purpose of closer coordination of fish an game laws in the Middle Atlantic States, an association of Middle Atlantic Fish and Game Commissioners has just been organized.

A campaign jointly undertaken by the American Red Cross and the American Nurses Association to raise $100,000 in this country as part of a world fund to provide nursing scholarships in tribute to Florence Nightingale, the founder of modern nursing, was begun yesterday with a meeting at the headquarters of the New York led Cross Chapter, 315 Lexington Avenue.

Liberal arts colleges must "reconstruct" their curricula with a view toward keeping their students in touch with the problems of contemporary civilization if they are to continue to exercise their social function, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University declared last night.

The first in a series of four "Red Letter Thursdays" in aid of the Montvale Summer Camp will be held today at Le Bijou, 2 East Fifty-sixth Street, under the auspices of the Westover Alumnae Society. Already many reservations for luncheon, dinner and supper have been received.

ALBANY, April 18. -- Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller making his annual report to the Legislature today, announced continued improvement in the State's credit rating. He pointed out that considerable temporary financing had been necessary, but said that it had been accomplished under extremely advantageous conditions.

As one of the student "strikers" of last Friday may I congratulate you on your editorial of April 16, "Students and War"? Your main point is well taken: that if he merely states pacific intentions the student is not going far enough -- that he should also lend his weight to every agency designed to prevent war.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- President Roosevelt's definite opposition to the McLeod bill, which would provide for government payment in full to depositors in closed national banks now in receivership, was made plain at the White House today.

Another indictment, charging conspiracy, was returned yesterday by the April grand jury against Louis J. McNally, 46 years old, removed superintendent of the City Home for Dependents on Welfare Island. Named with him in the bill, the details of which were withheld under the law, was his wife, Margaret C. McNally.

Presenting figures from records at Albany which showed the total cost of Westchester governmental units last year to be about $64,000,000, Miss Beulah Bailey of the State Tax Department told about 150 members of the Westchester League of Women Voters at a meeting in White Plains yesterday that the most important thing for Westchester's government was to cut its cost.

OTTAWA, April 18. -- Valuable tariff concessions to Great Britain and other members of the British Commonwealth, designed particularly to allay British dissatisfaction with the result of the Ottawa agreements, were announced by E.N. Rhodes, Canadian Minister of Finance, in his budget speech to a gold price of $35 an ounce.

NEWARK, N.J., April 18. -- After playing fine ball for eight innings, the Newark Bears went to pieces in the final stanza today and lost the opening game of the International League season before a crowd of 14,000.
The Giants ran roughshod over the Phillies for the second successive time at the Polo Grounds yesterday, winning by 6 to 2.

There is disappointment in State administration circles over the tax returns from the sale of alcoholic beverages. Consumption, according to the Albany correspondent of THE TIMES, is only about half of what was expected. This is due not so much to the cost of licenses and the rate of taxation as to, first, the many restrictions imposed upon the sale of liquor, and second, the prices exacted by the dealers, wholesale and retail, and restaurants.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 18. -- Concluding more than thirty years of active service on the Rutgers University faculty, Dr. William Hamilton Kirk, Professor of Classical Languages and Literatures, and Dr. Walter R. Newton, Professor of German Language and Literature, will retire June 30, President Robert C. Clother announced today. Each professor will receive the rank of professor emeritus.

The New York State Association of Master Plumbers, closing its annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, voted to endorse the bill of Representative Wadsworth which would authorize the RFC to make loans to property owners for the repair and renovation of dwellings and commercial buildings.

Margarete Dessoff and her Dessoff Choirs, consisting of the Adesdi Chorus of women's voices and the A Capella Singers of New York, mixed voices, gave their third concert of the season at the Town Hall last night. As is customary with this group, the program was entirely unhackneyed and included compositions of distinction.

Leon Fraser, president of the Bank for International Settlements at Basle; Jacob Gould Schurman, former United States Ambassador to Germany, and H. Gordon Selfridge, with his daughter, Viscountess de Sibour, are among the passengers due to arrive this afternoon on the Bremen of the North German Lloyd.

Because many holders of wine and liquor licenses are believed to have applied for new licenses rather than renewals of their old ones, the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board has abandoned its intention of giving to the police a list of non-renewals for police action.

RYE, N.Y., April 18. -- The Westchester subcommittee of the Cardinal's Emergency Committee of the Laity in the Archdiocese of New York gave a dinner in the Westchester Country Club here tonight to celebrate the tenth anniversary of Patrick Cardinal Hayes as Cardinal, his fifteenth anniversary as an Archbishop and his twentieth anniversary as a Bishop.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 18. -- Fordham's baseball team set back Yale today by 14 -- 3, the Maroon practically duplicating its 11 -- 0 success here last season. The same pitchers who started the 1933 game, Ed Estwanick and Davis Harrington, faced each other today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18. -- Laymen and clergymen of the Protestant Episcopal Church were advised here tonight to take immediate steps toward catching up with the "advanced social thinking" of the Bishops.
